text:
OK - if you are like me, you will look at the ingredients and instructions for this receipe and say to yourself "Jeez people, what is the big deal?" Well- don't do it. I chose this receipe simply because I had a whole chicken, not a lot of time, and needed to cook it.  I have NO idea why the combination of these ingredients or this cooking method (I followed it EXACTLY as written, but used real butter) yields such a wonderfully TASTY bird...but it does!  If you don't try this, you're missing out. If you do try this, I venture to say that, you will be very pleasantly surprised!

text:
I used the advice that the reviewer on the recipe page said:  Use in combination with Moist Garlic Chicken.  I sliced 8 garlic cloves and put in cavity, under skin and on top YUM!  I also sliced 2 small lemons and put one in cavity and the other on top.  Put 1/4 cup butter in cavity and 1/4 cup sliced butter on top. Put cut celery in cavity, and then salt/peppered all over. Roasted for 2 hours - turned out perfect.  The GRAVY was AWESOME!!  Some flour with the oils, then chicken broth and all the browned bits from the pan and juices from carving.  This was my first roast chicken.  Will make over and over!!

text:
I used a combination of 2 recipies from this site. This one and "Moist Garlic Roasted Chicken". It turned out perfectly. For my seasoning I used garlic powder (instead of onion) and lots of salt and pepper both on the outside, and in the cavity. Next time I will probably add some rosemary. The other recipe called for stuffing the cavity with lemon slices and garlic gloves. The flavours were great, and it turned out really juicy. Thank you for this recipe :)

text:
great recipe. though i had to use different ingredients to season the chicken. i didn't use salt and pepper. i used Cajun seasoning and rubbed it outside and inside the chicken. i stuffed the butter/margarine inside the cavity like how it says in the recipe but instead of using onion powder, i stuffed onion wedges inside the chicken instead. i also aded crushed garlic cloves and about 2-3 sprigs of rosemary. if you're lazy to baste chicken, you can inject olive oil (or garlic infused olive oil) in the breast and the thigh to make it really really moist. it's such a no-brainer. thanks for the recipe.

I am a personal chef. My clients love this dish. I stuff the cavity of the bird with celery and put celery in the roasting pan around the bird. No other seasoning besides the onion powder. I do use butter, and it's great, but margarine would be just as good. This is one of the tastiest low-salt dishes I've found. Thanks for the help.

text:
I tried this recipe tonight because of all the reviews but I didn't really think it would be as good as people said because the ingredients were so simple...boy was I wrong! I've roasted chicken for a long time with different types of seasoning and I've always been pretty happy with the taste and tenderness of my birds. I can't figure out what it is about this recipe--it's not *that* different from what I've done before but my chicken tonight was so juicy and flavorful that I was astounded. My husband declared this the go-to recipe from here on out. I followed the recipe except for 2 small variations: I placed the chicken on top of thick cut slices of onion in my baking dish --something I learned to do to keep the chicken off the bottom of the dish but also to keep all the yummy juices and cooked bits as well as to season the juices for the gravy--and I added 3 whole garlic cloves to the cavity, other than that I took what I thought was a chance and followed the intstructions. I'm glad I did...and I will again and again and again. Thanks for such a great recipe! This is going into my Tried-and-True set of recipes

text:
I have tried many different roasted chicken recipes. This is so simple and so good! I had no celery, so I put chunks of sweet onion inside the bird. This recipe got the results I was looking for tastewise. Unfortunately, the 1/2 c. of butter is not good healthwise, but I think it may be the price of getting a yummy, juicy roast chicken. I made a nice gravy from the pan sauce for the mashed potatoes. This is definitely a good method. But maybe not the healthiest way to prepare chicken. I made this in a blizzard in Wisconsin, when we needed something warm and comforting, so it was really great for us.

This is FANTASTIC. Don't be tempted to embellish on this one, folks... it really doesn't need any help. The chicken is amazingly moist and tasty. The only thing that I did differently is that I rubbed some of the margarine and spices under the skin of the chicken as well as on top. Once you're done and have only a carcass left, be sure to save it for making stock later!

userID:
1594003
Display Name:
Victoria Skelly
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2152797.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
wow!  I cook a lot and this is an awesome way to cook a chicken.  Whoever says it isn't flavorful, either isnt seasoning enough OR is so used to supermarket roast chicken that they forget what a good basic roast chicken taste like.  I followed directions but did add some things i know I like....  I stuffed it with the celery and also a clove of garlic and an apple, I put butter and chopped garlice under the breast skin and rubbed a pat of butter on the chicken.  I also used garlic salt in addition to the other spices.  My bird was 7lbs and I cooked for 2.5 hours and let it sit a half hour.  With 45 min left in cooking I added cut up potato drizzled with evoo and sprinkled wth herbs de province.  After I took the chicken out I put the potaots back in for 15 min and shut the oven off and let them crisp.  Before serving, I stuck the chicken under the broiler for about 90 seconds to crisp up the skin.  This was SOOOO moist!  Thank you thank you!  Oh I almost forgot, I sliced an onion and cooked the chicken up on the rings so the juices would flow under it making it easier for basting.  I then took the juices and scrapings in a fry pan and brought it to simmer adding chicken broth and a tblsp of flour and mushrooms.  What a delicious gravy!

text:
Best EVER! I had 5.5lb bird which took about 2 hours. I put some butter (not margarine) under the skin and quartered 2 yellow onions and tossed them in the pan around the bird, half way through added about 2.5 cups of water into the pan. Also I bumped the temp up to 375 for the last 15-20 minutes to crisp up the skin. It was the juiciest, most delicious chicken I've ever had! Served with green beans sauteed in olive oil, garlic and course salt as well as garlic mashed red potatoes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/60097.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is fantastic - I've made roast chicken dozens of times but will rate this five stars for the EASE + deliciousness of the end result. Used butter in place of margarine, and was very generous when salting, peppering and onion powdering the bird. Basted every 20 minutes. The highlights: the tasty, crispy skin at the end, and the milk gravy made with the drippings. To make gravy (DONT skip this!! You'll be glad you didn't): after letting chicken sit for 30 mins, transfer it to a plate and scrape all remaining brown bits and drippings into skillet. In a separate bowl (or mason jar with lid), mix 1 1/2 cups whole milk and 2 tbsp. flour together until blended. Pour into skillet with drippings and whisk constantly over medium heat. When bubbles appear, continue whisking for another minute then remove from heat. Taste and adjust seasoning as needed (mine needed salt). The gravy is to die for!

text:
This was the highest rated "roasted chicken" recipe that popped up, so I figured I can't go wrong.
Well, I was wrong and the recipe went wrong too.
I followed the directions, except since I wanted roasted veggies with my dinner, I put a bunch of cut-up carrots, potatoes and rutabaga under the chicken.
Now I don't know if that's what threw the whole process off, but the chicken was very undercooked when we sat down to eat it after the 30 minutes rest time (I don't have a thermometer, but with a five-star recipe, I trusted the time indicated).  
Back in the oven for another 30 minutes, chicken was done, but tasted bland. Veggies were also undercooked (I will blame the recipe for that too).
Very disappointing overall. Should have read the none-popular reviews before embarking on this.  Lesson learned.  :(

country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. So simple and so delicious. What I did was melt 1/2 cup of butter in the microwave and added crushed garlic to it and rubbed it all over the chicken. Then I sprinkled salt, black pepper and dried crushed basil leaves. I didn't stuff it with anything but I will next time. The key is to place the chicken breast-side down in the pan. The breast comes out so moist and juicy that way. Also, I was scared to leave the chicken uncovered for the 1 hour 15 mins (I'm used to covering it for 30mins then uncover for 30 minutes to ensure well-cooked chicken), but I left it uncovered the whole time and it was perfect! The smell will be so good but just resist the urge to open the oven door since everytime you open the oven door, the temperature decreased 25 degrees F, which extends cooking time.

text:
Prepared as written. I cook all roasted meats on a cookie sheet lined with foil. Easy clean up and the air seems to circulate better cooking the meat more evenly. I placed chopped carrots, onions, potatoes and garlic gloves on the cookie sheet and cooked with the chicken. When the meat and veggies were roasted I took the pan drippings in a sauce pan and added 3/4c of water mixed with 1 tbsp of flour and 1 tsp of salt to make the gravy. This was awesome - very tasty! Thank you.

I will definitely pick up a whole chicken on grocery day and follow this recipe correctly. My apologies to those of you that get upset when a recipe is changed and then rated.

Display Name:
MOLLYSMAMA
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/173968.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
MMMMMMM.... good!  The secret is don't use light margarine - or anything that's got water in it. I use 1/2 olive oil & 1/2 butter - melted together and then brushed over chicken & splash the rest inside. I add an onion inside with the celery.  Adding any broth or water makes for more stringy, chewy, dry chicken. Also, don't cover it, you don't wanna trap any steam. I cook it low & slow at 325 until the thermometer reads 170-ish deg.  Then take it out to rest & let the temp. rise to 180.  Chicken heaven!  This works with cut up chicken pieces too!

text:
This was great! I was amazed by how juicy it actually turned out. Something I did that I think helped the flavor was adding garlic cloves to the cavity, no celery.  On the skin and under the skin of the breast meat I added rosemary and put butter under the skin as well as on the outside. It was just as good, if not better than the rotissere style chickens you can buy at the grocery store. A little more effort, but cheaper!

text:
I haven't even used this recipe yet and I already like it. I wish though I could reply to some of these idiotic reviews! You don't use butter, the recipe calls for margarine, it is not the same thing.  If you use butter and complain of it being greasy, blame yourself. By reading the reviews there's a lot of people who can't follow directions. The seasonings are to taste. If you think it's bland, that's your fault too. You didn't use enough. If you used a bigger chicken than the recipe called for and your chicken wasn't done, that's your fault! You cannot cook a 4.5lb or 7lb chicken the same amount of time as a 3lb bird. Let's do the math... If it calls for a 3 pounder to be cooked for 1.5 hours, that's 30 minutes per pound. Adjust your time accordingly. DUH! And to the person who said 180°F was too high and the temp should be lowered to 165°F, oh my gosh, the recipe said 350°F.  DO NOT blame the recipe giver if you didn't follow the recipe! READ PEOPLE! READ! Good grief.

text:
At first glance I was attracted to this roast chicken recipe because of it's simple ingredients and ease of preparation.  I didn't have much time to get this dish together and in the oven.  I didn't have to compromise on taste or moistness because this combination yielded the "juiciest chicken" I ever made according to my Hubs…and I have made a LOT of chicken over the years.  The only thing I adjusted was the cooking time since my chicken was larger than the recipe called for.  Using a meat thermometer will ensure you have fully cooked your chicken.  Thank you for a real keeper.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Wow!  This really is as good as everyone says!  When I read the ingredients I thought, "What's the big deal?"  But it was outstanding!  It must be the butter on the inside that makes it so moist.  Yes, I used butter, not margarine, because margarine is very unhealthy so I don't ever use it. People think that margarine is lower in fat than butter, but that's not true--compare the labels.  Plus, margarine contains very unhealthy trans fat, which butter does not.  Anyway, I also used half garlic powder, half onion powder.  (1 1/2 tsp of each.)  Seasoned quite liberally with Kosher salt & pepper.  My chicken was just over 5 lbs so I cooked it for 2 hours on 350 convection, basting once.  Other than that didn't change anything.  Absolutely delicious!  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
So I have borrowed many recipes from this site but never bothered to sign up to rate them until now. I have made roasted chicken many ways especially with lemon, garlic and onion in the cavity.  I was tempted to do that but didn't want to be a hypocrite.  So I made it exactly as written...I even bought margarine...which I haven't done in years and the chicken was FABULOUS!!!  My husband & son are the pickiest eaters and use the "jar gravy" with any roasted meats...well not this time.  I didn't even heat the gravy before my 10 year old was shoveling it down.  He wasn't even that hungry and ate most of it.  In fact, he left the potatoes on the plate (as a major carb eater, he never does that)!!  My husband finished his plate (used no gravy) and went to the stove to pick more of the chicken out of the pan!!  I will be definitely adding this to my recipe collection and making again!  What makes this simple recipe so good is the onion powder (flavor) and celery (moisture/juiciness).  Next time I make it, will make sure chicken is room temp, super dry and take my time cooking/resting the bird.  It was late and I rushed it...but chicken was still very juicy!!  For a side, grill some red onions and potatoes in separate pan...awesome combo!

text:
I made this last night. I usually use a Carousel Rotisserie which sits on the sink but I wanted to see if this way of cooking chicken was better. It was just as good and juicy. I only had to clean up one pan instead of taking appart and cleaning the rotisserie which takes awhile, so thats a plus. I only used 3 tablespoons real butter and one large stick of celery cut into 3 pieces in the cavity. No butter on the outside. Followed directions using all the other ingredients. I always boil the neck in water while the chicken is cooking to add when making my gravy just to make sure I have enough, my husband and I love gravy on our mash potatoes.I made my gravy using the drippings in the pan, the broth I cooked and flour for thickness. This was the best tasting gravy I have ever made before. I am going to put away the rotisserie and never use it again. This is now on my menu list. Thanks for this GREAT RECIPE.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This came out pretty good with the butter basting, as I wanted to make just the basic chicken without the vegetables in the roasting pan this time. I needed to increase the cooking time to 1.5 hours though, which seems more standard to me than the 1 hour 15 minutes it stated. My thermometer read 170 degrees at 1 hour 15 minutes. 

I would also add to the instructions to baste one more time just before serving because the meat did get a little dry sitting out for the 30 minutes to rest, but then tasted really good when i put some pan drippings on it later. I didn't use celery because I didn't have any, and I used half a stick of butter which would be about 1/4 cup instead of the 1/2, which made adequate juice and browning.

I also basted mine a few times during cooking because cooking without a cover can dry it out.

This is a delicious bird!!!!  I made a few changes... I seasoned inside and out with salt and pepper only... then I stuffed the cavity with the celery and 2 carrots.  For the butter, I used my poultry herbed butter; consists of minced garlic, poultry seasoning, and a garlic and herb soup mix!!!  I blend all the flavors with the butter and drop some in the cavity, smear it all on the outside of the bird, as well as under the breast skin!  Beautiful and delicious!  I baste it at about the half hour mark and let her go!!!!

This made the best chicken ever!  I was looking for something that would add flavor to my chicken dumplings so I decided to roast the chicken instead of boiling.  I followed the recipe exactly but I added about 15 minutes to the cook time because my chicken was larger.  I also added thyme and parsley to the salt and pepper.  I hate celery so I skipped that but the chicken was wonderful.  I can't wait to make it again.

Had chicken leg quarters on hand. Made a bed of thick sliced onions & celery. Rubbed legs w/ recommended spices, covered w/ more sliced onions and cooked @ 375 for about 1 hour. Put chopped yams, potatoes, carrots, & garlic cloves mixed in kosher salt and EVO in two other pans in the same oven. Everything came out at the same time and dinner was served! Chicken was moist and delicious! Drippings would have made awesome gravy.

text:
I don't really like chicken, so I begrudgingly made roasted chicken at my husband's request. This was really good and I am near impossible to please when it comes to chicken. This chicken was SO juicy. We stuffed ours with celery, onion, and garlic. Yum! Next time we will add some more seasoning, but I can't dock the recipe, since seasoning is all a matter of preference. This chicken was so easy, it tastes like it took a lot more effort than it really did. My husband loved this chicken, I've never seen him attack roasted chicken quite like this. =) 

If you're looking for a delicious, fool-proof recipe, this is the one! 

(It did take a little longer than the hour and fifteen the recipe calls for, so I highly recommend a meat thermometer. It's a life saver!)

text:
When I am cooking, there is not much that upsets me more then when I find a consistently high rated recipe that I am excited about, prepare it exactly as directed, and am completely underwhelmed by the result.
That was the case here. The chicken was juicy, yes, but completely bland. I also had to cook it for over 2 hours!! The cooking time is not long enough. The skin did not get crispy and was lacking flavor as well. This recipe was not good enough to justify all of the fat (1 stick of margarine!)called for, and I will not use again. Sorry:(((. Roast chicken rotisserie style from this site is much, much better.

WOW!  This chicken was SO easy to prepare, very moist, and VERY flavorful.  I won't roast a chicken in any other way in the future.  Few small changes:  I lightly buttered the skin of the whole chicken first.  Also, since I had no onion powder, I used garlic salt instead with great results.  Lastly, I put half a red onion, and a few cloves of garlic in the cavity with the celery.  Delicious recipe.  Highly recommended!

New to the site, and new to the real world (living in my own place for the 1st time with my sweetie!) and had a nice farm chicken from family on a farm in Altoona PA.  Never roasted a bird on my own before (other than helping on Thanksgiving holiday) and wanted to do something with the whole chicken.  I found this recipe and saw how simple it was and sounded tasty, so decided to give it a go, and I'm really proud of how it came out for my first try!  I did put my own lil flavor add to it since I have some whole garlic, and read that paprika browns chicken nicely, so added that to the seasonings.  I did find as one post mentions, that cook time was too short, but I was determined and hungry lol, and another hour or so I had a great meal.  Thank you for sharing this!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Juiciest chicken I have ever made...must be something with the celery sticks because I have put other items (lemons, onions, etc) in the chicken cavity and never had it come out as good.  I made it on a cast iron skillet with onion and potatoes in it. Placed chicken right on top of the veggies.  Also used real butter...margarine is going to kill you way before the real stuff does. 

One note on cook temp -  I cooked until chicken was 160 degrees, which was right at about 1 hr and 15 mins.  Chicken is good at 165 degrees.  If you pull it out at 160, it will still cook and get up to 165.  I check this using a meat thermometer to be 100%.

text:
Delicious, tender, tasty, super juicy, easy peasy roasted chicken. This was so tender that it fell right off the bone when I was saving the leftovers for another meal. I used kosher salt and a good Tablespoon's worth (maybe a bit more) and mixed the salt, pepper, and onion powder together and went from there. The onion powder gave this a really good flavor and I loved how simple and delicious this is. I had a 4.5 lb. chicken, used salted butter, and roasted it for a total of 1 hr and 45 minutes covering the top loosely with a piece of aluminum foil when it started looking golden brown. I let this stand for almost 45 minutes while preparing the sides and this was such a moist juicy tender chicken. I love this recipe and we loved this meal! Thanks so much.

country:
None
text:
My hubby said that this was the best roast chicken ever!  It ruined El Pollo Loco for him.  Costco chickens are great, but be sure to increase the cooking time as these tend to be bigger birds.  I've been making this roast chicken recipe for years and it comes out perfect each time.  I have modified the recipe a bit for ease.  Once your chicken is cleaned and rinsed, pat dry.  Rub with olive oil and sprinkle a Greek rub or whatever floats your boat.  I use a stick of real butter that I cut into 6 pieces.  Two squares go into the cavity, along with 2 sprigs rosemary and celery.  The rest of the butter goes under the skin at the top and the bottom of the breast along with additional rosemary.  Perfect!

This is on the menu for tonight.  Love roasted chicken....

text:
I'm a big believer in using only real foods so I switched the margarine for butter. I also used a little rosemary in the cavity. It was an awesome roast chicken and I can't wait to make it again. The only thing I'll do differently next time is put a little foil over it towards the end of cooking. I cook my bird breast side down so all the juices make the breast juicier, but in this case my wings and legs got a little crisp and dry, so the foil will prevent that! Yummy. I made stock with the bones last night and I'll make soup with the stock and leftovers today.

text:
This is a great recipe when you're pinched for time. I'd previously made the roasted "sticky" chicken recipe with lots of great reviews but I didn't have 5 hours to spare.....and this one certainly did the trick. I butterfly'd a 5 lb chicken to have it cook faster (a tip from my sister-in-law) and added baby carrots around which got a nice flavoring from the melted butter. I put the celery right underneath the split. It came out very tasty and made for great left overs.

text:
Bland. I was very generous with the salt and pepper and onion powder. Apparently it wasn't good enough to penetrate the meat. This recipe would do better if you quartered an onion and shoved it in the carcass. I mean, why wouldn't you use real onion vs onion powder?! Meat was not fall off the bone and that is a prime requisite for baked/rotisserie chicken for me. Needs more time than 1:15. There are much better recipes here... but what do I know... this is 5 stars for most people, right?...  :/   Disappointing. This chicken is now soup material.

Like the recipe says this is a moist chicken, however, it is a bit greasy. Te chicken skin contains fat that is rendered, then when you add the oleo (or butter, if you prefer) it makes for alot of fat. Delicious, oh yes. But too much fat. I think I'll try olive oil for a better ingredient.

text:
This is foolproof. lol its like "Chicken for Dummies". I usually add whatever I have on hand and stuff it in the cavity: either onions, celery, apples, fresh herbs... you get the idea. It's nearly impossible to mess this one up! :) Instead of just "arranging" the butter around the exterior of the chicken, I mixed some extra onion powder in with the butter and rubbed it under the skin. The skin will already crisp on its own without the additional butter. By rubbing the butter compound on the meat it produced a perfectly moist bird!

text:
Juicy and very tasty!!  This was the first time I ever roasted a whole chicken.  I wasn't sure if I was supposed to cook on a rack in the roasting pan, but I did.  I added a few changes as I was feeling a bit creative.  I filled the cavity with garlic cloves, onions and carrots and put extra onions, carrots and celery in the bottom of the pan with some white wine.  I poured melted butter over the top of the chicken and then put it in the oven to bake.  I basted the chicken every 30-60 minutes while baking.  It was moist and very tasty!  I served the chicken with two side dishes from this website:  Pumpkin Casserole and Jamie's Cranberry Spinach Salad.  Yummy!!

Juicy but bland as a vaseline sandwich.  The recipe poster said people go silent when eating this, I have to wonder why they wouldn't.  In my family it's considered rude to talk with food in your mouth, just a thought.

The taste was so blah that I cut the meat up and used it on grilled pizzas with pine nuts, garlic, feta and yellow tomatoes.  The rest went into asian chicken noodle soup.

All in all this is a basic recipe for cooked chicken, something that a home ec class would make.  It reminds me of the stuff my great grandmother would eat, although, even she would have added a sprig of parsley or some carrots to this.

text:
I signed up with allrecipes just to leave a review. Yeah, it was THAT good and THAT simple. I can't tell you how many roasted chickens I've made in my adult life - so many different methods, cooking times, cooking temps...this one is IT. Forever! 

I made two roasted chickens on a rack, side by side (I buy them from Costco and makes meal prep real easy). I cooked at 350 for 2 hours. I didn't have time to baste, and that did not effect the juiciness or flavor. 

Wonderful and simple! My entire family ate it up, and that includes two very finicky kids who usually complain that even the juciest cuts of any meat are "dry". It passed the test!  Thank you!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the recipe exactly as written, because I like to do that first, and respect the cook who posted it. I often do add my own "touches" later, but always try the recipe as is first. And yes, exactly as written, this chicken is totally tender and delicious. Simple yet totally flavorful and juicy. Like many other readers, I sometimes add extra herbs, or cook the chicken in a roasting pan with potatoes, carrots, onions, etc. I have also found that using clarified butter instead of margarine works fine too. Regular butter tends to burn because of the milk solids, but clarified works nice. A slice of citrus in the cavity with the celery adds a nice touch, like orange or lemon. Wrapping the wing tips and drumstick ends in foil before putting in the oven keeps them from burning and drying out. 

But again - just as written, this chicken is top notch!

text:
I am an excellent cook, get rave reviews on my cooking, am asked frequently for my recipes,  and have  been cooking  over  40 years. I say all that NOT to brag, but for whoever happens to read this review will know my frame of reference and understand I am not new to cooking. I read a review on this recipe that said her chicken was not done after 75 minutes so I set the oven at 375 for 75 minutes. Chicken was NOT done and dry.  I followed the recipe to a tee. Switched my oven  to convection bake for 20 more minutes. Sadly, I do NOT recommend this recipe to anyone.  Normally I roast my chicken in a cooking bag for 60 minutes @ 350 and it ALWAYS   comes out tender, moist, and full of  flavor.

text:
I've been cooking for over fifty years. I don't know how many chickens I've roasted over the years, but this is the best yet. It was moist, tender and flavorful. I prepared it exactly as written, except we don't use margarine, so I substituted butter. I tied the legs together and stuck a skewer in the opening of the cavity to close it. Since it was a 5.5 lb bird I roasted it for a little over two hours. I love finding a recipe that requires ingredients I already have on hand and this one fits the bill.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Making this recipe was the first time I've ever roasted a chicken, and I am blown away. I followed this recipe exactly except that I used butter instead of margarine (I don't cook with margarine), I put some  of the butter underneath the skin of the chicken on the breast, and instead of following a time for the cooking,  I used an instant read thermometer to tell me when the chicken was at 165 degrees fahrenheight. My oven runs really hot and the skin and drippings were a little toasty by the end, but this is seriously the most moist chicken I have ever had, and the skin was so flavorful!

I deglazed the pan with a little dry sherry and then scraped up the fond and put these drippings into a saucepan with some whole milk and flour to make a delicious gravy. I served the chicken with Crash Hot Potatos from The Pioneer Woman and Oven-Roasted Asparagus from this site. I love this recipe and will use it often!

text:
I was skeptical at first because the ingredient list was so simple but when I first try a recipe I like to follow it exactly and if anything  I will modify it the next time. I am happy to say that this ingredient list does not need to be modified. I subbed in butter for the margarine but that's it! This chicken is delicious and juicy and my whole family (hubby, kids, mom-in-law) love it. I always use this recipe to make roasted chicken. I probably made it about 50 times by now. One thing is that the cooking time may vary depending if your chicken was thawed from frozen, or the size of your chicken. I usually check the chicken after the time specified in the recipe and sometimes I end up cooking it longer (30 - 45 min).

text:
I almost never buy whole chickens because I don't know what to do with them other than make soup in my pressure cooker.  For some reason I was craving roasted chicken, so I bought a 5+ pounder, then found this recipe.  So easy, no chopping of a copious amount of vegetables (I managed to cut up the celery stalk -- LOL), and OMG, so SO good!  One pan, 2 hours in the oven (mine was 5 lbs., not 3), and it was delicious.  I even managed to carve it (sort of).  My kids loved it, and it wasn't nearly as salty as the store-bought rotisserie chickens that I normally buy if going for a whole chicken.  Will definitely make again!  I altered the recipe only slightly -- sprinkled with garlic powder and paprika on top before roasting, but because we don't eat the skin, I don't think it made much difference.  My only reason for only 4 stars was I was unprepared for how much juice pours out of the cavity when starting to carve (is it all the butter?) so made a huge mess all over my cutting board/counter/floor.  Ugh.  BUT, worth it!

None
text:
The preparation instructions here are great, but the recipe seems to have a major flaw: if you actually cook it til the internal temp reaches 180, the bird becomes terribly overcooked and dry. Only after making it this way did I look around the web for what other respectable sites are recommending for internal temperature - and the USDA recommends 160. Many say they take it out at 150 or even sooner, b/c the poultry will keep cooking in residual heat. I will try it again and this time call it done sooner.

text:
Omg. Like everyone else, I wanted to know what all the fuss was about. THIS CHICKEN IS FANTASTIC! I used creole seasoning just because I'm a southern gal and seasoned salt is life, basically. So I didn't sprinkle the bird with onion powder because the seasoning contains that, but stuffed half an onion into the cavity with the celery. I roasted uncovered for an hour and then covered and baked for an additional 45 mins or so until I reduced oven temp to Warm. This was my first roast chicken, but it will forever be my go-to recipe. Simple yet delicious! Thank you!

text:
Very juicy! I used butter because margarine is not a real food. I followed other suggestions such as melting butter with the seasoning and then brushing that on the dried skin inside and out.Inside was celery, lemon, rosemary. I tucked roasted garlic under skin and I then seasoned some more with Montreal chicken. My birds were almost 6lbs each. I started at 450 degrees for 15 minutes. Then cooked 20 min. per lb until 160 degrees. Crispy skin which is my favorite part and very juicy meat. Got rave reviews at dinner party. The best part is that I cooked two so I have another meal ready to go or to freeze.

userID:
3932761
Display Name:
cathy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
13
favoritesCount:
109
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As another reviewer said, don't be fooled by how simple this is!  This is the best roast chicken and so easy.  I find seasoning the cavity a challenge (what do you do, stick your whole hand in there?  Throw the salt and hope it covers evenly?) so what I do is melt the butter (sorry, I don't use margarine) and drizzle that over the chopped celery. I then season the chopped celery (butter makes seasoning stick nicely) and stuff the bird with the seasoned celery.  I make sure chicken's skin is dry before I pour a little more melted butter on and rub that around.  Season the skin (I use a generous amount of good kosher salt or coarse ground sea salt).  I start the chicken in a 400 degree oven to crisp up the skin then reduce to 350 after just 15 minutes, and roast 20 mins per pound at 350.  Crispy golden skin, moist even in the breast.  A few times I've added chopped onion inside rather than onion powder, and the last time I just used celery and salt and it was still delicious.

text:
Currently reading through the comment section and it occurs to me that most people don't realize you're supposed to cook any poultry 20 minutes per pound so therefore if its under cooked or overcooked it because you did not look at the weight of your bird before you cooked it. so hopefully this helps people out.  I'm making this chicken but I added garlic and onions into the cavity also. I still only used s&p on top. plus, I rub Evoo on top of the skin and I put only maybe 2 tablespoons of butter/margarine on the inside with the onions and garlic. normally I do my grandma's recipe which is just salt and pepper and some oil on top baked with potatoes and carrots along side the bird but I felt like doing something a little bit different . This time I'm actually roasting it vs baking it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this recipe a 5 for how easy it is to follow. I have roasted chicken before, but needed something, if only for roasting time information, because I could not find a chicken with a pop up thermometer. I did change this a little bit, as I was out of celery. rubbed margarine all over the chicken, under the skin, and inside the cavity. I seasoned the bird inside the cavity and on the outside with cajun seasoning, rosemary and onion powder. Then I sliced several cloves of garlic and inserted them inside the skin, throughout the cavity, and tucked into the wings and legs. I basted once, about an hour into roasting. This was really moist and flavorful, and the drippings made a delicious gravy. I ended up with only 1/2 lb of chicken leftover that I will put in a casserole for tomorrow night.

text:
This is so simple yet fantastic! I add some more spices like garlic powder and cayenne just because I love a lot of flavor, but even without those things the chicken is amazing! I also don't have the problem that some have had with it exploding everywhere in the oven. I'm thinking that maybe those people have crazy ovens or they're putting the chicken too close to the heat source. I've used both real butter and margarine and it's great either way. Try it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This does make for a juicy chicken ... but you definitely need to tweak the spices a bit if you want flavor.  This recipe is meant just to give a juicy chicken, nothing more.  I placed small amounts of butter underneath the skin of the chicken, which made for extremely tender chicken breast, but aside from that, the flavor was lackluster.  I've used an onion in the cavity of a whole chicken and it has the same effect, so no need to buy celery if you don't have it on hand.  I used the drippings from the chicken and butter and whipped up some gravy to put on it, which made it delicious, but otherwise would have been very bland.  I think I'll stick with the Sticky Rotisserie Chicken from the site instead.  Thanks!

I followed recipe to a T and the bird was not done in the amount of time stated.  We had to forgo eating chicken that night and instead I made chicken and dumplins with it the next day.  The meat was tasty, but wasn't enjoyed the night it was cooked which bummed me out.  To get a perfect moist chicken cook it at 250 degrees for 5 hours.  Turns out great every time and I wish I would have went with my gut instinct before cooking this one.

text:
This chicken comes out so moist and tender-heaven on a plate. My husband and kids request this meal often. My only additions are minced garlic and pepper into the cavity of the chicken along with potatoes, carrots and onions scattered on the outside. I also sprinkle some additional onion powder on top of the chicken with pepper and minced garlic. During the last 30 minutes of cooking I will generally add some baby portabella mushrooms (you don't want to add them at the beginning of cooking because they will shrivel up and loose flavor). This is a keeper that I will add to the family recipes :) Thanks!!!

HEAVENLY. Who says you need to starve and only eat junk as a student? I just buy a whole chicken, follow this recipe and pop it in the oven and forget about it. Then I have delicious leftovers for the next few days. The only thing I did differently was I used garlic granules, and a healthy sprinkle of cayenne. I didn't end up using celery at all and stuffed the chicken with garlic bulbs, lemon and some onion wedges. After the chicken cooked I made a gravy of all the juices on the pan with chicken stock and corn flour/ cornstarch.

text:
DELICIOUSLY YUMMO 6lb Chicken!! 
Like another cook, I used REAL BUTTER, added 1 Lemon(cut in half and squeezed half into chicken and stuffed it and the other half squeezed on top), and added 8 GARLIC CLOVES(4 inside, 4 placed under skin with butter). 
*Since I had a larger chicken(6lbs) i cooked 350 for 2hrs(BREAST SIDE DOWN), then I flipped it when it came out of oven and covered to rest 30min. 
*I cook all my chicken in a Pampered Chef baking bowl. 
**Served with boiled potatoes & carrots, steamed broccoli and then tossed veggies in the drippings from the chicken.
~This will be a staple at our house.

text:
I'd give this recipe 10 stars if I could.  I've made this at least twice a month since I found the recipe.  Who would have thought such a simple recipe could produce such a succulent chicken.  I expected the top to burn but it didn't.  Just don't make the mistake of putting the margarine or butter under the skin instead of on top.  I did that once and the top skin burned badly. Lesson learned.  Great recipe.  Sometimes I bake a whole chicken just to have in the frig for quick fix recipes using cooked chicken.  Makes GREAT sliced chicken sandwiches too with mayo on lightly toasted bread and topped with sprouts and slivers of sweet red pepper with a Kosher pickle on the side.

My husband made this as written for dinner tonight.  It was very easy and very moist.  One tip, my father-in-law, who was a butcher, told me is that even after you cut it, let the pieces sit in the juices from the bird.  The meat is so incredibly moist this way!  Can't go wrong!

Display Name:
lostmyseatagain

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/768156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great basic recipe.  I did not try it as suggested, but made some changes.  I squeezed one whole lemon onto the chicken and quartered another--stuffed half into the chicken and dropped the rest in the pan.  I didn't have a real roast pan, so I cut thick onion rings to raise the chicken in my 9"x12" baking pan.  I cut the remaining onion into big pieces and scattered it in the pan.  I ignored the time and went only by the thermometer.  I also used way more than 1 tbs of onion powder.  And of course, when butter is an option, it's the only option for me!

The chicken was super moist and the meat fell off when we tried to break the legs off.  Fantastic as leftovers too.  I used the drippings on red skinned mashed potatoes.  The lemon adds a great kick--I imagined that the flavor would have been too bland otherwise.

text:
Turkeys, fresh or frozen, are not widely available in Ukraine where I will have 2 Christmas days as theirs is celebrated January 7th.  So I bought 2 roasting chickens, stuffed them with a savoury, sage, butter, chicken broth, celery, onion, salt and pepper, garlic bread dressing .... rubbed the outside with soft butter and sprinkled with salt, pepper, onion salt, and garlic  .... convection roasted at 175 C for 90 minutes .... turned out pretty well and was quickly gobbled up.

text:
Excellent recipe! I tweaked it, as always, but my modifications still tasted great. My chicken was 5.6 lbs, so I cooked it longer. I used garlic powder rather than onion, put onion slices under the chicken, 3 whole celery sticks inside plus 3 shallots inside the cavity (would've used garlic but I was out) and then carrots and potatoes surrounding the chicken in the roasting pan. Delish! SUPER moist with a nice crunchy skin. I am looking forward to the leftovers, which will be chopped and made into chicken & rice casserole!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6990179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted to make the Fast Chicken Soup Base from this site but I didn't have a roasted chicken laying around. I DID have some chicken leg quarters and half breasts with skin and bone, so I used 2 breasts and one leg with this recipe. Instead of rubbing the outside of the skin with Country Crock, I treated it like a turkey and pulled the skin away from the meat and added spices and butter in the "pockets." When it came out of the oven, I almost changed my mind! The skin was so crisp and flavorful that I couldnt sacrifice it to the soup stock, and that was fine because I added all of the cooking juices and bones instead. I can't wait to try this again, and there is plenty of room to adjust spices for different tastes. Thanks so much!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/664651.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love having roasted chicken, since it's so easy and results in wonderful smells tastes and a wonderful presentation.  While I was making it, my mother did have a few recommendations for it though.  She suggested instead of arranging the dollops of butter around the outside of the chicken, to instead rub the butter all over the chicken so it gets maximum coverage.  I used garlic and onion powder, and even though I thought I added enough spices it could have had just a little more.  Don't be afraid to cover your chicken in spices, I think it takes quite a bit to get the best flavor to the meat and skin.

Also remember to not be my mom and push past the resting period after it's done cooking and just cut in and serve, you'll have very very dry leftovers in no time.

text:
This is the moistest, flavorful chicken I have ever made and soooo simple to do, too! 
I used butter not margarine. I seasoned the chicken with the salt, pepper, and garlic powder (basics, but you can season with whatever you like). I also sauteed onion, celery, and pears and put them in the cavity with the butter. I rubbed the chicken with the butter (a little under the skin) and then left some dollops on the top.

text:
this was perfect. i always use a variation of this recipe when roasting a chicken. i always use real unsalted butter(which i always have on hand), salt, and pepper.   usually i stuff with a quartered yellow onion, whole garlic cloves, thick lemon slices, celery, and halved carrots.   last time i made this i cut up some root veggies(turnips, purple carrots, potatoes), basted them with the buttery juices from the chicken, and threw them in the pan with the chicken for the last ten minutes of cooking. so so yummy! even my picky toddler was gobbling it up.  i always try to use fresh, seasonal, local, and organic ingredients when possible, it really does make a huge difference in taste.

text:
I also chose this recipe because I had a couple whole birds and was short on time.  I did add some garlic and thyme to the salt and pepper rub, but other than that I followed pretty much exactly.  I left the house and it cooked for about 2 hours with no foil or basting, and it was still superb.  I made gravy with the drippings:  Simply transfer all the liquids to a saucepan, dissolve several tablespoons of cornstarch in a bit of cold water, and add cornstarch mixture to liquids until desired consistency.  Tastiest gravy ever!  Super easy recipe with great results.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very easy, and the juiciest chicken I have ever made! We prefer white meat, so instead of a whole chicken, I did just some bone-in chicken breasts. I cut the celery stalk in chunks and put it in an 8x 13 pan, and laid the breasts on top. Then I sprinkled them with garlic powder (my mistake, as the recipe calls for onion powder, but it was fine) and dotted them with margarine. I used much less margarine than the recipe calls for, about a teaspoon per piece. These were large, meaty breasts so I cooked them for an hour or so. I let them stand for awhile after removing from the oven. They turned out very moist and tender. I was looking for an easy way to make chicken for all those recipes that call for "chopped, cooked chicken" and I think I've found it! I'm going to use this chicken in the Holiday Chicken Salad recipe from this site, but it would be delicious as a stand-alone entree, and the drippings looked like they would make an outstanding gravy.

text:
Very tasty and juicy.  I've made this a few times.  Make sure if you are using a bird bigger then the three pound to add at least an extra 10-15 mins per pound. (I've had problems with my home grown 4-5lb birds taking way longer to cook).  I also didn't have a roasting rack so I cut up potatoes, onions and garlic and just stuck it under the bird with a little salt on top.  Makes the veggies yummy but really greasy.

My 4 lb roaster came out just like the picture. Delicious and moist is right!!    I rubbed the outside (and breast under the skin) with room temperature unsalted butter.  Then I sprinkled the top with a little Lawry's seasoning salt, a generous amt of Lemon Pepper seasoning (next time will use more), garlic & onion powder.     I added  1/4 cup white cooking wine to the pan while it cooked, but next time, I'll put the chicken on onion slices so the back skin can crisp better.     Hubby loved it. Will make again!

text:
Very good, did listen too some of the poor reviews and put a few garlic cloves and thyme in the cavity as well, I normally make a roux gravy, but i guess with the butter this one came out awesome, Pan Gravy  Rich in the natural meat drippings left in the pan after cooking roasts, steaks, chops, and fried chicken. One cup of gravy is good for 3lb. roast.  For each cup of medium gravy use: 2 tbsp. fat 2 tbsp. flour 1 cup liquid (water, meat stock, or bouillon cube broth)  Remove meat to warm place. Pour off clear fat (not drippings). Measure amount needed into small sauce pan. Measure liquid into roasting pan; stir and scrape all of brown drippings loose from pan -- heat mixture if necessary; set aside.  Add flour to fat in sauce pan; stir together until smooth. Cook over low heat, stirring steadily until it is bubbling.  Take pan off heat. Gradually stir in liquid and drippings from roasting pan. return pan to heat; bring to a boil, stirring constantly. Boil 1 minute. Season and serve.  Flavor boosters: Cook meat with seasonings such as bay leaf, peppercorns, onion garlic, celery salt, or other favorites. Add bouillon cube of either beef or chicken. Try different liquids, such as potato water, water from cooked mild vegetables, consume, cream, sour cream, milk, tomato, or vegetable juice.  If gravy turns out less than perfect. If gravy has lumps: Pour through a strainer before serving.  If gravy is too greasy: Skim a paper tool across gravy or Skim gravy with lettuce leaf  gra

text:
Very good plain, old chicken.  I used the same ingredients (didn't measure), and 3 uncut stalks of celery.  Rubbed seasoning and margarine between skin & meat of each breast, then all over the outside.  Baked uncovered (in a Pyrex dish) at 350 for 1.5 hours.  The skin was very crispy and there were no juices for basting.  It sat around for an hour then was reheated in microwave:  Was still tender and moist.  Super quick prep and no muss/no fuss cooking.

text:
This is a great jumping off point for adding your own spices as well. I make this whenever I find a whole chicken on sale but use Santa Maria Seasoning which is Garlic, Parsley, Salt and Pepper. Tonight I decide to add some red potatoes, swirling them in the pan with some olive oil first and the same seasoning. I like to put pats of butter inside the skin (loosening it first with the blunt edge of a butter knife). I plan to return the potatoes to the pan after setting the chicken out and covering it w/foil. They should crisp up nicely. A simple easy staple in our house.

text:
This recipe makes a great chicken, so I thought I'd modify it to work for a turkey.  As a turkey newbie, I was looking to make a bird that was juicy and flavorful without being too wacky for my family to enjoy.  I stuffed it with an entire stick of butter and celery.  I also added rubbed sage to another stick of butter that was softened and dabbed on the outside of the turkey.  Then I roasted it at 325 for about 5 hours (for a 14 lb. turkey).  It was delicious and perfect turkey.  Thanks for sharing this outstanding recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am not a health nut who goes for the lean white meat of the chicken. But this recipe made me want more of the breast meat because it was soooo juicy. I look up recipes to know the best cooking method, temperature and some idea for seasonings. I seasoned this with the usual S&P, margarine is a must, you are right, then i mixed together lotsa garlic powder, some chili powder, paprika, thyme, ground coriander, some cumin, a dash of cinnamon...just eye-balling them depending on what i wanted it to taste like and rubbing the chicken all over with it. Uggh, it was unbelievable. The drippings, i strained them and made a gravy out of it with same amount of flour, some water until i liked the consistency. I did not even have to season it. Served it with some simply seasoned mixed veggies and boiled small potatoes to balance the multi-layered flavors of the chicken which was pretty bold, the perfect combo. Thanks again for the recipe. This is my go-to roast chicken cooking method as well.

text:
I doubled this recipe believing that I would have more people to feed this Thanksgiving, (we don't eat turkey). My brother helped me with prep for dinner and we made a brown sugar rub, added a halved lemon and onion to the cavity instead of celery. I try and cut out salt as much as I can so I only used the black pepper. We also omitted the onion powder as the rub had so many other spices in it besides brown sugar--which was rubbed on the outside and in.
Since this was the first ever chicken I've roasted, I followed the cooking guidelines as if it were life or death, I'd hate if my family got sick because I didn't cook the chicken right--that said covering the chicken at the end really holds in the heat and gets the meat to the temperature it should be at. The chicken was devoured within minutes of hitting the table--this recipe was definitely worth the 5 stars and raving reviews.

region:

country:
None
text:
I used butter instead of margarine as that's all I had and I don't buy margarine normally. I followed the direction except I had no onion powder and used a little onion in the cavity. The chicken breasts were not juicy at all and next time (there will be a NEXT time!) I will cook this breast side down. I lined my pan with foil and OMG the gravy/sauce was incredible. One of the top ten gravies I have ever tasted, and that's saying alot because my father is a gravy magician. I know there was a lot of chicken fat in it, but this thin light sauce drizzled over roasted vegetables was outstanding! I didn't thicken it or add anything else to it at all, it was salty enough. Overall, fantastic recipe, use as much marg/butter as you want and my trick with the salt is to not just rub it on, but massage it very well into the skin, the better you do this, the better the skin. Dry breasts, A+ sauce.

None
text:
Incredible!!! Very juicy and tasty.  However, 1 hr and 15 min at 350 is not enough time. I took mine out after 2 hours and it still could have used another 20 min. Use a meat thermometer. It will take 2+ hours to reach 175C. I also used butter instead of margarine. There is not a lot of juice in the bottom of the pan so butter doesn’t burn like margarine does. I also had some fresh sage that was starting to getting a bit wilted so threw that in the cavity just to use it up. Will definitely do this one again.

userID:

Display Name:
Carrie Kiger
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4115978.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We just discovered that the oven in our new house came with a meat thermometer, so I was anxious to try it out. I went to the store this morning to buy a chicken before I actually looked up a recipe. This was, by far, the best rated recipe, but I didnt have any celery and I was ready to substitute and onion and/or carrots instead. I was also prepared to add a little garlic powder and paprika to the skin. 

After reading several of the reviews here about following the directions precisely, I bundled up my 3 year old and made a second trip to the store. Boy, was I glad I did!

I followed everything precisely, and it turned out beautiful. I was worried about it being dry, since the directions don’t have you basting until after it’s finished in the oven. Don’t worry - it’s nowhere near dry. 

I will definitely be adding this to our menu, without changes or substitutions. 

Oh, and my new oven’s meat thermometer worked perfectly!  I had a slightly over 4 pound chicken, and it helped me know I needed to cook a bit longer than the recipe called for. I think I had it in for another 30 minutes. Bottom line - watch the internal temp and don’t change the oven setting at all. 

Great recipe!  Very juicy and delicious skin!

text:
I don;t remember that I have ever even roasted a chicken before but this did come out so moist it was unbelievable.  The only changes I made was in some of the spices that I put on the chicken.  I added garlic salt , memphis style bbq spice, and lawry's seasons all to the outside and garlic salt and chopped garlic to the inside.  OMG!  what a flavor.  When we were done eating on it I boiled what was left and made soup out of it.  The soup was soo good I had to roast another chicken just so I could make more soup and can it for later.  I have the third chicken ready for the oven and we will eat on it for a bit and then I will boil it as well, save the broth and shred what meat is left for future dishes like chicken noodle or chicken and dumplings etc.  So far this is one of the BEST  recipes I have found here.

One of the ways I roast chickens, with exception, I use real butter, as it is healthier than margerine.  Keep the chicken moist during roasting by separating the breast skin from the meat, and put your butter and seasonings in between so they are directly on the meat.

text:
I made this as instructed the first time.  Just delicious.  The second time I brined the chicken in kosher salt and water for 3 hours the day before (2quarts water and 1/2 cup kosher salt).  Then I patted very dry the outside and inside of the bird and let it sit uncovered overnight in my fridge to crispen the skin more upon roasting.  THEN, the next day, I added slices of lemon and garlic under the breast skin and in the cavity with the butter and celery.  My husband loves this so much EITHER way and it is truly a moist, flavorful bird.  I, myself, have never before liked roasted chicken until THIS original recipe.  MAKE THIS IF YOU HAVEN'T YET!

Followed directions to a T and it turned out so moist that everyone wanted 2nd's. My step-granddaughter wanted the carcass to pick what was left and eat the celery, LOL. She's 9-years old. I didn't make a gravy out of the drippings, I just spooned the drippings onto the carved chicken pieces. Served with pan roasted parmesan, garlic potatoes and collard greens. Delicious!!! I want to try this on my Thanksgiving turkey! BTW, those who say they cooked it for 1 hour and 15 mins and it was not done? That is why you tent it for 1/2 an hour, to allow it to cook itself the rest of the way.

text:
Not bad as written, BUT, as any good chef/cook will do, you ask yourself, "What can I do to make it better?"So I did!
I am a big fan of Rosemary or Lemon Pepper with my chicken. So I cut the celery stalk in half, added 2 sprigs of Rosemary and tied it together with butcher twine.
Yesssss, the flavor was awesome.
Next time I will make a compound butter with Lemon Pepper and rub under and on the skin, and if the moon is full and the wind ain't blowin', I'll stick some Rosemary up it's .........Cavity.  
;-)
I had to bake longer  than 1:15 to get a safe temp in my dark meat. It was more like 1:40. I covered the breast with an aluminum bra to give it a bikini look. I did that at about the 45 minute mark. She sure was sexy lookin'.  Sorry, no pics.

None
text:
I liked this recipe, however it did take longer than an hour and fifteen minutes. I think the temp is a little low. I started at 350 degree F for and hour and fifteen minutes, but the juices were still not clear. I turned up the oven to 375 and Keep checking it after 20 minute intervals. I'm thinking next time I'll start at 400 degrees covered with foil for an hour, then bring it down to 375/350 the rest of the time uncovered. I would also like to point out...you need to rinse chicken (if not doing a brine) and pat dry with a paper towel. Make sure you soak up the excess water inside the cavity as well. All and all the recipe itself is good. I will be using  it again.

text:
The only changes I made was to add 1 onion quarter with three whole cloves with the celery to the cavity.   I also added 1 cup of chicken broth in the roaster, cooked for 2 hrs. for a 3.6 lb. whole chicken.  Used 1 cup of broth with 1 cup of milk whisked with 2 tbs. of flour for the gravy seasoned with salt and pepper.  Served with mashed potatoes and asparagus from our garden.  Absolutely delicious, sad to say we have no leftovers.  I will be making this again.  Thanks for posting.  So very simple.

5285626
Display Name:
Maria-Elaina Bowman
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4133068.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Deserves more than 5 stars!  Simple recipe that is absolutely delicious, flavorful, and most importantly, moist.  This is a huge concession for me since I don't even care for chicken in the first place and was stunned to find that it was one of the best meals I'd ever eaten!  I used olive oil in place of the margarine (because I'm lactose intolerant) and it was still sensational. Otherwise I followed the recipe to a T.  Can't  imagine how much better it would be with butter (our household doesn't use margarine)!   This is a wonderful basic recipe that is incredible as is, or it can be spiced up a bit with any combination of flavors you'd like...garlic powder, fresh garlic, onions, carrots, potatoes, rosemary, sage, thyme, lemons, apples, oranges, greek seasoning, etc.  Can't wait to experiment!  The most important thing is to be generous with the salt and onion powder,  massaging  hard and well into every pore of the skin, as well as inside the cavity.  Don't forget to seal in those flavors with your choice of fat - margarine, butter, olive oil, avocado oil, coconut oil, etc.   Also, be sure to do the math as to the cooking time depending on how big or small your bird is.  The organic ones I get at the store tend to be much larger  (almost double)  the weight listed in the ingredient list. This recipe comes with my highest recommendation.  Bon Appétit!

text:
I know many people say you have to make this recipe as listed but I just could not. I have made chicken before but it has never come out this juicy and perfect. I pretty much followed this recipe with just a couple of adjustments.  I used a 5 pound chicken ( It was on sale) I try to never use Margarine. I do not believe it is good for you at all ( Just my opinion) . Since Margarine is mostly just a oil spread I decided I would use 1/2 cup of Olive Oil to replace the Margarine.  Some scallions, garlic cloves, and celery inside the bird and then followed all other directions as listed. Since it was a 5lbs chicken I did cook it for 1hr 30min and came out sooooo perfect. Made the perfect gravy with the drippings and milk. My fiancé said it was the best he ever had. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I do this with turkey and chicken both. I use celery, onion and either apple or lemon. Cut up veggies into big pieces and fill cavity drizzle a little oil over skin and dot with butter. They turn out very moist every time.
I put them breast side down also. Then the juices run into the breast meat not out of the breast.
Use celery to keep bird off of bottom of pan, if you don't have a wire rack.

country:
None
text:
This recipe gives you a really juicy roast chicken. but the only problem is that when you cover it by aluminum foil, the steam of cooking chicken washes away most of the spice and then it feels like a simple and not very tasty chicken. So I would recommend to cover it for a short time (about 10 mins) after you bring it out of the oven.and if you ,like me, enjoy real crispy and tasty chicken follow all the instructions but put the chicken on a rack instead of into a pan and then put it in the oven. That's it!

WOW! I added 3 crushed garlic cloves to the inside of chicken with celery, butter, and salt and pepper as directed. I don't have a roasting pan or rack so i quartered potatoes and 2 carrots skins on all and placed them on the bottom of my dutch oven and put the chicken on top. We didn't need to season the carrots or potatoes at all! Everything was delish! Will definitely make this again and again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Placed quartered potatoes, chunked carrots and few thick slices onion in roasting pan drizzle with olive oil, s&p, and big pinch thyme. Place chicken on top, drizzle with olive oil, s&p inside & out, sprinkle with thyme. Place few slices onion in cavity with 8-10 cloves garlic chopped in half and 1 stalk celery. Baked at 425 for 1 1/2 hours rest under foil 20m (for 5.47lb bird). I'm sure this recipe is delish as written, I just wanted to cook everything together, only 1 pan to wash! :)

text:
WOW.  I decided against all temptation to follow this recipe exactly as is and I'm glad I did because it was awesome, juicy, flavorful, fall off the bone delicious!  I did double it because my chicken was 6lbs.  I read a review that said theirs was undercooked, but all meat of equal measure cooks the same.  So I think maybe that person didn't know when you change the serving size the measurements of ingredients changes, but the directions stay the same.  So it sounds like their bird was bigger, but they cooked as according to the original serving in the recipe.

region:

country:
None
text:
I make my chicken the same way, except I stuff the cavity with an onion or two. Sometimes I get really wild and put a few bay leaves under the skin. The key to a juicy chicken is to fill the cavity with a veggie that puts off lots of aromatic steam. Yes, you can use butter alternatives (margarine, light or low fat butter substitutes, unflavored yogurt, unflavored greek yogurt, etc).

Followed this recipe exactly. I was having a busy day so it was quick.

There is nothing wrong with this chicken if you are a novice cook. This recipe calls for the least amount of prep, and turns out really well.

That said, once you have a few years of cooking under your belt, you will probably have a recipe on hand that has a lot more taste than this basic chicken.  '

I may make this recipe again in a busy pinch.  Thx for posting it!
Keep in mind, if you use an organic chicken, this recipe will be better.

first let me say, I appreciate all the reviews and everywhere they go.  I'd rather deep dive into a recipe with 1500 reviews than page through 1500 recipes with 1 review.  I don't want to waste time and money if I don't have exact ingredients and it's great to read someone else's experience.  that said.... I don't buy whole chickens, so I had some leg quarters, no onion powder, so I layered the celery and onions on the bottom, stuffed each portion with garlic and butter, and remaining butter on top.  sprinkled garlic power on top and baked as directed.  OMG awesome!!  juicy and moist, with great skin!  Sometimes it takes a village to cook a chicken...

text:
I've made this recipe many times and loved it every time!  Instead of a whole chicken, I'll usually use bone-in dark meat pieces.  Two nights ago, I baked two pounds of chicken thighs and scaled down the recipe accordingly.  Don't be afraid to be liberal with your seasonings--they really make this dish amazing!  EDIT:  I love the versatility of this recipe.  Just add your choice of seasonings and some type of fat, then bake it for 20 minutes per pound plus 15 minutes.  This time, I used garlic salt, pepper, and olive oil, and cooked my 4.5-lb chicken for 1 hr 45 min.  Yum!

text:
I definitely looked at this recipe and thought that it seemed way too simple and used way too much butter. But I followed it to a T (very generously salted, peppered and onion powdered) and it was... delicious. It smelled sort of like ramen when it was baking, and filled the house with that savory, buttery, meaty, oniony umami scent. We baked it at the exact specified temperature and time, forgot to baste the chicken at the end but DID tent it for 30 minutes, and it still came out amazing. The breast meat was juicy, the skin was crispy and flavorful, and the carcass made delicious soup the next day. Our guests actually fought over their favorite chicken pieces. We used a super cheap chicken, and will definitely be buying more whole chickens when they are on sale for this recipe. This is just as good, if not better, than my beloved rotisserie chicken. But next time, I will actually use margarine as called for instead of salted butter to cut down on cost. Don't be afraid to try this one - you will not be disappointed! Garlic, rosemary, etc. not necessary: all you need is this recipe!

text:
I have made this recipe too many time to count since it first appeared, I think it's my husbands favorite Sunday meal.  I follow the recipe exactly but I do lay the chicken on a bed of veggies because the timing and the temperature are right. When the chicken is done I take it out, put the veggies in a bowl and lightly tent the bird and do not carve it for a minimum of 30 minutes.  This gives me plenty of time to make my gravy  and mash my boiled potatoes.  Smart Balance (regular) is my choice of margarine.  I love that this recipe is so simple, I have been a bride for 52 years but a bride of 52 days will have equal success!

userID:
11659572
Display Name:
John Bills
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3

44

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5413966.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I modified, as I found this recipe after the trip to the store; had no celery, but I bought Stove Top stuffing (Herbs flavor), so that was cooked in microwave, then went into the cavity. Instead of using margarine, I dried the outside of the bird, then rubbed olive oil all over the bird. We used a mix of 5 seasonings (1 T each) in a bowl: Huey's burger seasoning (from a Memphis restaurant), Tony Chachere's seasoning, celery salt, onion powder, and Mrs. Dash salt-free garlic seasoning. I'm sure you can mix whatever sounds good to you, but these turned out fabulous. And we had a big chicken, 6 lbs, so  I followed the general rule for poultry roasting: 20 mins/lb, plus 15 mins, or 2 hrs 15 mins. One reviewer gave a poor rating because her 4.5 lb chicken didn't cook through, although this recipe clearly states this is for a 3 lb bird! I had to find the rule elsewhere, but it worked: our bird had a temp of 180F in the deep thigh after resting 5 minutes (birds will cook a little bit after you remove them from the oven, so a delayed temp is more accurate). Probably could've gotten out 10-15 minutes earlier, as long as the temp is at or above 165F. Made gravy with pan drippings, 3/4 cup of chardonnay wine, and flour/cold water mixture (about 1.5 T AP flour). Excellent!

Display Name:
NORMA47
isPro:

city:

None
text:
I used two chickens from  Costco, roasted  them about 1 hour 50 minutes, when cool took the meat off of the bones, simmered the bones and  skin in chicken broth, i  use  just Aldies chicken broth,  and drippings that were in the pan.  (don't use water) simmer about  1 1/2  hours, or till  meat and bones flavor the broth.  I then I strained the  broth for  my  soup.  Be sure to  used the drippings. I continued to make my soup, I  added onions celery carrots, when veg's were done I added  rice or noodles  and some of the  meat.   It makes a  lot, so I freeze  some of the broth and add the rice or noodles or whatever I'm in the mood for  when I  take it from the freezer you will never have better soup, but don't skim off  all of the chicken fat, that is what makes it  good and cures a  cold. (you can indulge one in awhile)I have a food saver so I freeze the broth in  a plastic container and when it is  frozen solid I remove  from the container and  vacuum  pack it. I usually freeze  4 cup containers because it it  just two of us.  I also  cube the cooked meat that I removed from the bones and  vacuum pack that in two or three cup packages for further casserole.  The  only way to make good  chicken soup is to roast the chicken.   Enjoy!

text:
This recipe is amazing.  I've never made a roasted chicken or gravy before.. and both were incredible!  My family couldn't believe it.  "This is fall off the bone good"..."This is restaurant good".  I added a few things.. I used 8 cloves of garlic (sliced), half of them in the cavity and half on top of the chicken.  I also used 2 lemons (sliced): one inside the cavity and one on top of the chicken.  I also increased the butter amount to 2 sticks of butter (sliced)-one under the skin and the other on top.  The only thing that was not perfect was the time it took.. The smallest chicken I could find was 4.79 pounds and it took 2.75 hours to cook.. but it was well worth the wait.  The gravy was scrumptious too:  After removing the chicken from the pan, I put the pan on the stove top on Med heat.  I mixed in 2 tablespoons of flour and a cup of chicken broth and stirred until it was starting to come to a boil.  It was so yummy!  I will make this again and again.  Everyone loved it, even my picky picky 5 year old.

text:
I hardly ever get around to reviewing/rating recipes, but I have used this one so many times I knew I had to make sure I got around to it this time.  I actually used this recipe for the first time when I was roasting a turkey for Thanksgiving, and I got such rave reviews that I tried it the next time I roasted a chicken with the same results.  My husband constantly tells people "you have to try my wife's chicken!"  Kids love it too.  The only changes I make are stuffing some Smart Balance (what I use for margarine) under the skin as well as on top of it. I also use a light sprinkling of poultry seasoning instead of onion powder.  I also flip the chicken over for the 30 minutes under the foil tent to allow the juices to flow down through the chicken from the breast.  I will never need another roast chicken recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely fantastic - I did this for my Easter Sunday dinner, made it exactly as directed, and it got rave reviews all around. It really is this simple - the chicken was incredibly moist and had a beautiful skin. And because we Southerners just can't serve any meat without some kind of sauce or gravy, I made a very simple au jus from the pan drippings, some added water and a small amount of chicken stock. Truthfully, I don't think the chicken really needed it - it was plenty moist enough; I just have menfolk in my family who can't stand the thought of not having something to spoon over the meat. I did this with a family-size roaster chicken, so it took a considerably longer time to roast (soooooo worth it, though) - but I was able to use the leftovers for a really awesome chicken salad. Hands down, this recipe is a keeper!

text:
Very moist and flavorful! I followed this easy recipe to a "T" and it came out just perfect! My friend was skeptical about the onion powder, because, like most folks, she has always roasted chickens with just salt and pepper. She was very impressed with the flavor, so if you're on the fence with the onion powder, I recommend giving it a shot. The chicken came out very moist as well.  I will give some of the credit to the bird that I used as it was truly free-range, organic, farm-raised, with no hormones or anything like that. Really fresh. My chicken was right at 3 pounds. I will continue to roast chickens in the manner since I see no room for improvement.

text:
I thought this recipe was entirely too bland to be so highly rated.  Juiciest chicken we've ever had in our lives.  Ever. It may have something to do with the fact that I accidentally cooked it upside down, I don't know.  I will happily accidentally do that all the time now!  The only thing I changed, besides the position, was the time and temp.  It was a 5 lb chicken and I only had 2 hours so I cranked it up to 375.  2 hours at 375 with a 5 lb chicken upside down yielded an amazingly juicy, fall off the bone, cut the breast with a fork chicken that I can't wait to make again!  Oh, and I used butter, not margarine.

text:
This is a great recipe! I prefer to have my chicken crispy on the outside, so I don't cover my bird and let it rest for the additional 30 minutes. Instead I just cook it for 15-30 minutes longer and cover with olive oil before seasoning. This yields a layer of crispy chicken skin on top of moist and flavorful chicken.

This is a good Paleo dinner. If you are totally dairy free use coconut oil instead of butter. I did 2 whole chickens in a roaster pan. One with onion and one with garlic. I have to say side by side the onion one was the better of the 2. I also used a quality salt (French sea salt)and pepper that I just mixed a bunch together and spread it on liberally YUMMY!!! will do again! I am using the left over bones to make chicken broth!

text:
I've tried this recipe now three times. The 2nd time I tried adjusting the recipe and it didn't come out nearly as good. Trust me and follow the recipe as written! The only thing you may need to adjust is cooking time if your chicken is a little bigger (generally 25 min per pound at this temperature). Also, make sure to allow enough time for the chicken to rest the full 30 minutues....makes all the difference! Super juicy! My husband has asked for this to be in our dinner rotation....frequently!

text:
I followed this recipe nearly exactly, using butter instead of margarine, and it was sensational. I grew up eating rather dry, tough roasted chicken, so I thought I would rarely roast poultry in my own kitchen. This was my first attempt, and now all I want to do is roast chicken. It was just too easy, and ridiculously delicious. I stripped the bones of all the meat I could and used the leftovers for chicken chilaquiles the next day. I do wonder if similar results could be achieved with less butter/margarine, but I don't know if I want to try...this recipe is perfect as is!

text:
Best chicken ever! I originally made this recipe exactly as instructed, because I hate reviewers who give less than 5 stars when they change things! I was not disappointed at all. The bird was moist and delicious. The second time I made it I used Emeril's All Natural Chicken Rub, instead of the salt, onion powder, and pepper (since they're in it anyway), also equally awesome! The take away for me is  that the margarine and celery are key! The spices you want to use can vary and the bird will still turn out awesome. Thanks for such a wonderful recipe!

text:
Did this a little different for time contraints.  Slightly defrosted, I put butter dabs under the skin along with the spices, and inside the caivity as well.  Cooked in the crock pot, first two hours on high for the semi frozen chicken, then finished about four hours on low.  This was fall apart delicious and moist, even the white meat.  The remaining liquid could be used for a soup base.  Doing it this way you don't get the roasted skin, but it sure is good and juicy.  The celery really seems to add something.  Simple and easy.

OMG. OMG. This recipe is simple, easy, and amazing. I wanted to make a good at home meal on a budget and my grocery store had roasting chickens on sale so naturally I did a search for roast chicken recipes and decided on this one based on the reviews and the fact that it didn't require a lot of ingredients. My bird was over 5 lbs so I had to roast it more like 2 1/2 hours. Other than that I followed the recipe to the letter. My boyfriend loved it and I didn't even have to argue with my 3 year old about eating his dinner. I will definitely make this over and over again!
