I read Jenny's review from 2/11/2008 and had to laugh, because my initial reaction - after reading the ingredients and cooking method - was also, "What's the big deal??"  But, Jenny was absolutely correct, because I followed the recipe EXACTLY as written (only extending the cooking time a bit, because I prefer a "browner" skin), and it came out PERFECT!!  It was the juiciest chicken I have EVER made ... we did not even need the gravy that I had made, as a "just in case it needs a little boost" precaution.  This recipe proves that sometimes, less IS best.  Thank you so much for sharing your grandmother's recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very moist and juicy. This really is a great recipe, but I have two small criticisms. 

First, the term "generously" is a little vague. If your chicken turns out bland, like mine did, then you may not have been generous enough with the salt and pepper. I don't use much salt and pepper usually so what seemed generous to me may have been a little light.  

Second, maybe 1 or 2 Tbsps less margarine.  I used a small roaster pan and there was just too much liquid in the pan.  

The chicken was very moist and juicy and everyone loved it despite it being pretty bland.  Next time I will add a bit more seasoning, maybe a pinch of garlic powder, too, and cut back just a bit on the margarine.

text:
This is exactly what it says ‘Juicy Roasted Chicken’. The only thing missing in the title is ‘Awesome’! The one thing I do differently is that I chunky chop onion up instead of using onion powder. The cavity is salted and filled with the onion, celery and margarine. Then I roast it just as written. I always make two chickens for this meal, because not only is it most frequently requested, but we always end up with guests! The gravy made from the roasted chicken is simply superb! It is most often served with a variety of roasted veggies. This is a definite keeper as it turns out perfectly each and every time!

text:
The  combination of easily on-hand, simple ingredients made this chicken superb!  I made gravy with a cup of water, 1/2 cup of white wine and a tablespoon of cornstarch added to the pan drippings......awesome!  The only problem I had, and I'm sure it's not the recipe....my roaster chicken's breasts were tough!  I never experienced this before!  But the dark meat and wings were moist and juicy.  Go figure.  I will make this again, hopefully my chicken will have tender breasts the next time!

text:
Omg! I am surprised! This was absolutely the most moist chicken I have EVER had! I followed the recipe but added more seasonings inside the bird as well as outside. In the cavity I did 1/2 stick of butter, bay leaves, 2 whole all spice, celery and carrots. I put the chicken in a dutch oven. in the bottom I put the other 1/2 stick of butter and then I poured in a little white wine. Covered and baked for 3 hours- took the lid off for the last 30- 45mins of baking. I had a 5.5 lb chicken. It came out so amazing! Thank you for this recipe! I will only make chicken this way. The breasts were juicy and tender. Much more with this recipe than with beer butt chicken. Thanks again!

This was the juiciest roast chicken I've ever made!  Mine was close to 6 lbs so I roasted for about 2  hours.  I added garlic powder and rubbed the seasoning and butter under the skin and rubbed the rest of the seasoning all over the chicken.  I also added garlic cloves inside the cavity. I was generous with the seasoning so the meat was tasty as well.

text:
I had a 6 lbs. chicken and goofed on the instant read thermometer so the breast meat was a bit dry, but not bad.  I had just enough butter and margarine combined for the job - putting some of the butter under the breast skin.  I added some garlic powder to the mix but otherwise followed the recipe.  This smells WONDERFUL in the kitchen - just a hint of how it tastes - so, so good.  I used the drippings to fry (already microwaved) potatoes in 'til crispy - which made the perfect accompaniment along with a simple green salad.  This is perfect for that whole chicken you don't want to bother cutting up and the day you just want dinner on the table without a lot of work.  Thank you so much for sharing this great recipe.  It will be a staple in our house.

text:
I was VERY surprised at this one!  During the cooking process I was wondering because there was no juice in the bottom of the roaster, and the chicken itself LOOKED dry.  But appearances are deceiving, all the juices were inside the bird

I added half of a large onion into the roaster, added water after I took the chicken out and boiled the well roasted onion for quite a while.  I also snuck in a gravy mix before thickening.  Since the juice all stays inside, I had to get a lil creative.  But it was all worth it in the end, VERY easy and tasty recipe.  Thanks a ton for sharing your family secret :-)

text:
This is the best roasted chicken I have ever made!  I added some things like 1/2 a small sweet onion and a 1/3 of a lemon to the cavity since I was out of onion powder.  I also baked for 2 hours at 300 since I had to leave the house while cooking it.  I checked the temp and it was higher than I wanted but it was still so moist and juicy, perfect.  We had nothing left but bones afterward.  The gravy was divine too!  I used Wondra flour (found at walmart) and gravy was done in less than 2 minutes!  Best meal I have cooked in a long time including thanksgiving turkeys!  Must be the butter but who cares???-----Update----I make at least once a week now as directed although last time I had no celery and used a meyers lemon since it was on hand.  It's my husband's favorite meal.

text:
Fantastic idiot proof recipe! I combined this recipe with the "Moist Garlic Roasted Chicken". I used 1 stick celery, 8 garlic cloves, 1 lemon, thyme, salt & pepper. I pushed the garlic under the skin of the chicken and stuffed the rest inside. I used garlic salt instead of onion. I think the secret is using butter/ margarine and covering the chicken and letting it rest for 30 minutes. 

My family gave me two thumbs up! So I will be making this again! It is really hard to please them, but this was the juiciest chicken I have ever made. The gravy we made using the juices was the best gravy ever. 

Thanks to the person who left the review who did the recipe and won best chicken! This is going to be my secret weapon!

 Thanks grandma!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-10-17T18:24:19.747
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
5590579
Display Name:
JennyEdison
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
30
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had gotten a big toaster oven that has a rotisserie function that I was dying to try out.  I only had select ingredients on me, so I had to improvise. It came out DELICIOUS-the best roast chicken I've ever made.  I had a 3.5 pound bird, and marinated in olive oil & smartbalance spread with the onion powder, salt and pepper 4 hours in advance.  I pulled the skin away from the flesh and rubbed it in. I tucked in several cloves of garlic under the skin. I took it out of the fridge 1.5 hours before cooking to take down the temp and for the bird to relax.  I stuffed the cavity with a few scallion stalks, a head of garlic (chopped in half, still in the skin) and 10 red grapes.  It was the only fruit I had on hand, and based on other recipes, there seems to always be a fruit or veggie to add water content, thus, I tucked in the grapes.   Then I skewered the chicken using the rotisserie spit, used a needle on dental floss to tie the wing tips together and the drumsticks together. Floss is a great option when you don't have anything else!  In 1.5 hours at 350 degrees, convection on and rotisserie function on, I had a PERFECT golden brown bird that basted itself and it wasn't sitting in its own oil or drippings, so not greasy at all! I took the drippings, took off a few tbsp of fat, kept all the brown bits of meat in the roaster drip pan.  I took it to straight to the stove top, added a cup of Swanson and whisked in less than 1/4 cup of flour slowly.  It was SO scrumptious!

I was floored by this chicken. WHY was it so good?!? Even the white meat was incredibly moist and delicious. I have never seen my kids vacuum up chicken so quickly; one of them didn't even like chicken until I put this on their plate!   I didn't have celery and I used butter instead of margarine. My chicken was 7# and of course I can't remember how long it took to cook, I just set the timer for 2 hours and then checked the temp until it was done. I served with stuffing w/ apples and onions and it was a huge hit. Thank you!!!

text:
I was a little disappointed after reading all the rave reviews.  This wasn't a bad recipe, but not much better than any rotisserie chicken you could pick up in the grocery deli - only more time, money, and work involved.  My daughter and I both thought it was just okay.  I tried very hard to use all the margarine recommended, but ran out of places to put it!  I think that most whole chickens anymore are closer to 5 lbs. (mine was) and require at least 1 1/2 hrs.  I needed about 1 3/4 hrs. to get this chicken to the acceptable point.  We had plenty of leftovers, but I'm not feeling highly motivated to use them.

text:
What on earth is it about this simple combination that can possibly turn out SO delicious?  I suppose it's the celery that keeps it so moist.  I used real butter in the recipe and followed everything else exactly.  My chicken was only 3/4 thawed, so it took 1hr and 45min to cook.  I was concered about it drying out from cooking so long so I basted it every 10 minutes after the 1 hour mark.  My goodness was it ever moist and juicy.  One of the best chickens I've ever eaten. It reminded me of turkey dinner.

I was skeptical because of the ingredients (or lackthereof) but after reading the reviews, I decided to try it and it was phenomenal! I didn't change anything in the recipe because I wanted to see how it would turn out. I have never had a chicken so JUICY and it literally fell apart in my mouth. There wasn't too much juice/drippings when the bird was done so I used 1/3 can of chicken broth, 2 cans of cream of mushroom, the drippings and a handful of flour for gravy and it turned out great. I will definitely be cooking this again soon!

text:
The only reason I didn't give this a 5 star rating is that the internal temp of 180 seems too high.  I waited for the internal temp of the traditional 165 and then covered it with foil for 10 min.  I don't know if this was a typo or if they really wanted you to cook until the internal temp was 180 if so the cook time is more like 2 hrs. not 1 hour and 15 min.  Otherwise the favor was better than an roasted chick I have ever made. Will be adding to the weekly rotation!  Thanks for such an easy recipe.  Mom said it tasted like her French Mother'chicken that she used to make!!  :)

Oh my gosh.  I was looking for an easy recipe to roast a chicken for some chicken noodle soup.  I can't believe how juicy this is.  I followed the recipe exactly, except that they didn't have 3 pound chickens at the store, so I used a 5 pound chicken, 7 Tbsp butter (4 inside the bird, 3 outside) and 2 stalks of celery.  The smell in my kitchen within 10 minutes of putting this in the oven was amazing.  I can't wait for the kids to come home from school and smell it.  I have been taking nibbles off of this since it was ready.  We will be lucky if there is any left for the soup!

I LOVE roasted chicken, and have my share of recipes I use on a rotational basis so as not to get bored of the same flavors...but this recipe, by far, is THE BEST ROASTED CHICKEN I HAVE EVER MADE! I changed it up a bit from the original recipe based on other reviewers...I added about a half inch of white wine (I used  a Pinot Grigio) to the bottom of the pan, and I added celery salt generously over the whole chicken and omitted the onion salt and added garlic powder. A favorite from this day forth!

text:
This was a great recipe, thank you.  I did add a few extra seasonings (celery salt & garlic) and more butter.  The extra butter was not necessary afterall, there was a lot of fat/grease once I removed the chicken from the roasting pan.  The drippings made for a lovely gravy.  I added baby red potatoes (quartered), celery chunks, carrot chunks and onion to the roasting pan when I started cooking the chicken.  The veggies got seasoned with the same as the bird.  Everything was fabulous!  Thank you for sharing this one, it's a keeper and the whole family raved about it.

Had a random whole chicken in the freezer, and needed something simple for Shabbat dinner, as I just started school again and my schedule is crazy.  I stuffed the margarine and some sliced onions into the chicken Thursday night and lay the chicken on top of some diced carrots, onions, and potatoes. Will definitely make this again!

text:
This was really good,  I had a whole chicken and needed to make room i my freezer.  I seasoned with salt pepper and added a little onion and garlic powder. When i did the butter inside I added lemon slices instead of celery because i didnt have any and also placed a few on the outside. Chopped up some red potatoes and seasoned them well. Placed them around the chicken as it baked. Turned out great!

text:
This was an incredibly moist chicken!!  I did add butter under the skin as other reviewers suggested.  Also, I used a variety of spices (garlic salt, onion powder, garlic powder, seasoned salt, coarse sea & himalayan salt, garlic & herb rub and ground pepper).  WONDERFUL flavor!  (Note: the recipe is for a 3 pound chicken, mine was nearly 7 pounds and took a little over 2 hours.)  One other thing, in a covered baker I cut up celery, carrots, red potatoes and yellow onions, topped with the same seasonings I used on the chicken, as well as added some fresh garlic.  Wonderful accompanyment!!  Thanks for a great recipe that will definitely be a staple in my monthly recipes!

This was really tender and juicy and had a simple but good flavor. Roasted at 350 for 1.5 hrs and covered with foil for another 30 min. Came out great!

text:
FANTASTIC! I have, in all my years of cooking, never fixed a whole chicken - always used breast for everything. I was going to use the slow cooker recipe but thought I would give this a try instead - I AM GLAD I DID! This was so good, the meat was moist and the outside was nice and crispy. The only thing i will do next time is use less margarine, I think I added more then the recipe called for, because I really did not measure. I also used the Smart Balance Light and it was great.  I wanted to add that I ate some of the breast meat whenit was 'cold' about an hous later and the flavor was just popping out! thanks so much for sharing - I will make again and again!

This chicken was fabulous!!!  It was extremely juicy and flavorful...a BIG hit with the entire family.  I made a couple of additions:  I sprinkled the entire bird with as directed, but also added garlic powder to the mix.  Also, on the inside, I baked a few cloves of garlic and an onion (in addition to the called for celery).  My husband was impressed.  Said he didn't know I had that in me--not quite sure how to take that.  Lol.  Great recipe--keep an eye on time though.  Mine reached the recommended temperature of 180 degrees well before the called for baking time.

text:
I am really good at poultry over all but had little experience with a whole bird except for a turkey. I looked this recipe up and my god it is FANTASTIC!!! The first time it was good the second time was even better. I took a splash of turkey broth in the bottom of the pan, patted the bird dry rubbed it down with Olive oil and a variety of spices -garlic,onion,paprika,adobo and such it is a great set it and forget it. Plus if you want to make sure it is cooked enough buy the pop up timers they are easy, cheap and I havent ever had a problem. Thanks for the great tips!

country:
None
text:
I've never had a roasted chicken as Juicy as this from a store, restaurant, or home cooked! Changed it a little. Didn't have celery, so I put a 1/4 onion wedge in the cavity. Instead of just salt/pepper, I rubbed the whole bird with butter, then made a blend of garlic pepper, thyme, red pepper flakes, paprika, onion powder, garlic powder, rubbing it over the entire bird. I also sprinkled garlic powder in cavity. I wrapped it twice in saran wrap and refrigerated for 2 hours before cooking. I put 1 cup water in pan with fresh cut potatoes and carrots, then the chicken. It's ridiculous how juicy, moist, tender, and flavorful this turned out! A+! Posting a photo too!

text:
I just had this for dinner and it is sooo good.  I used I Can't Believe It's Not Butter Light.  I stuffed the cavity with crushed garlic cloves, celery, onion, and parsley.  I made gravy from the drippings and served it with green beans, corn, and home made stuffing.  I had a 4.2 lb roaster and it cooked quickly at 350F.  I have a gas oven, that may make a difference in cooking time.  Keep your meat thermometer on hand! I'll definitely use this again, enjoy!!

text:
This turned out AWESOME, my husband, out of the blue, said he thought it was terrific and I should make it again!  I pretty much followed the recipe and advice of the original submitter, although I didn't have celery, so I put onion and garlic cloves in the cavity instead.  I rubbed with thyme, sage, salt and pepper inside and out.  Then I placed the margarine as directed.  I didn't baste until I took out of the oven.  Also, I cooked the chicken upside down (oops) and it came out fine.  It was a 5lb bird and I cooked for 2 hours (which might have been too long, but didn't affect the outcome).

text:
This was sooo good, and so easy!  I did make a couple of changes, as per the suggestions in another review:
I sliced up six cloves of garlic, and two small lemons, and shoved that into the cavity along with the celery and butter.  I tucked a couple of the lemon slices and a few slices of the garlic under the breast skin.
My chicken was a little larger (5 pounds) and it took two hours to roast.
It was absolutely delicious, and juicy!
YUM!  Will definitely make again!

text:
This recipe had so many rave reviews, I had to try it per the recipe, with no changes. I had a 5 lb. chicken, so I had to cook mine for almost 2 hours, but besides that, I prepared the recipe as written. It was FABULOUS. After the first bite, my husband said, "Oooh, I might eat myself to death tonight!" Which, coming from him, is a big compliment. Haha! I added 3 cups of water to the drippings while cooking and made gravy with flour & water while the chicken was waiting to be carved. We could have drunk the stuff! To die for. I will never roast a chicken any other way. So simple, so easy, so delicious. Fall off the bone, yum. Thanks!!

This recipe is right on - very tender, juicy roasted chicken. I am NOT a cook but my family loved this and polished off every morsel of a 5lb chicken. I love this recipe ... anyone can do it. I changed the onion powder to garlic powder and omitted the celery (I didn't have any on hand). I put 3 garlic cloves in the chicken cavity and seasons the outside/inside of the chicken with Herbes De Provence.  I also quartered a few small yellow potatoes and drizzled them with some of the margarine, and seasoning them with salt, pepper, garlic powder and the Herbes De Provence.  Magnifique!!

text:
For this recipe, I also used different suggestions from previous reviewers.  I used butter and rubbed it all over the chicken and added 3 tsp in the cavity.  I filled the cavity with lemon slices, 5 cloves of garlic, slices of oignon, salt and pepper, garlic salt and some sprigs of rosemary. I then put garlic salt (had no powder, salt, pepper, a little bit of thyme and paprika on the outside of the chicken. I then squeezed a little bit of fresh lemon juice over it and cut up small pieces of garlic over it. I really enjoyed the chicken, it was tasty, but I had to cook it approx 45 minutes longer than what was called for. I rated it a 4 only due to the cooking time.
Very Yummy
Served with Fried rice

region:

country:
None
text:
This was my first time roasting a chicken, and I could not be more pleased!  I did follow the advice of some reviewers and added a lemon and onion to the cavity of the bird; I also used garlic-pepper salt, which resulted in a flavorful, crispy skin. The meat itself wasn't salty enough, but it was so tender and juicy, it didn't matter.  Everyone can just salt to their own taste this way. This is also a very economical dish; I bought a 5-pound chicken for $4.00, and it fed four people (including two BIG men!), with some left over. An added bonus:  this makes the house smell better than any potpourri I've ever used!

text:
This was the best roasted chicken ever!  I used garlic powder instead of onion salt and I sprinkled on a little thyme, too.  This gave it such a wonderful flavor!  It's even better when you run your finger under the skin and put some butter and seasonings underneath as well as on top of the skin.  It's even more flavorful this way.   The meat was so tender it was falling right off the bones.  The leftovers tasted wonderful, too!  I served with baked sweet potatoes and steamed broccoli and it was a tasty combination.  Can't wait to make this again!

This chicken is awesome!!  Extremely juicy--when I pull the leg off the cooked chicken you can see a pool of juice! Super easy if you have the time.  I use smart balance instead of butter which works well.  I have also had to increase the cooking time on occasion since it wasn't cook throughly. text:
I made this chicken with soy butter instead of regular butter and it STILL was tender, juicy, and delicious!  (This is often not the case with milk-free substitutions in recipes).  The only other change I made was putting a cut up onion inside the cavity with the celery (I didn't have onion powder).  For a side dish,  I also peeled a few potatoes and roasted them with the chicken, basting them a couple of times.  This is one of the best-tasting easy prep dishes I have found.  It will be one of my new standards!

text:
great recipe. nice, simple and ive actually been doing it similarly for years. instead of dollops of butter in cavity and outside the bird, i soften the butter a bit in the microwave and then i mix a little garlic powder, onion powder, and paprika into the butter and i smear the butter underneath the skin on breast and legs and them whatever is left over i smear inside cavity before stuffing with celery and an onion. i do it under the skin to add more seasoning to the meat itself. and maybe a light sprinkle on top of skin as well with a little pepper.

None
text:
This recipe yields a great chicken.  My family loves it.  I knocked off a star because the time to cook is totally inaccurate.  If you go by the time listed, then your chicken will be raw still.  I use a meat thermometer and also wiggle the leg.  If the leg wiggles easily, it's done.  You will need a meat thermometer for sure to make sure your chicken is not raw.  I do use real butter because that is better than margarine.

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-12-16T17:35:01.803
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
25196865
Display Name:
CajunKitchen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This indeed is a wonderful roast chicken recipe!  I used the ingredients exactly as written, but I did slice an onion to place the chicken on when roasting.  I slide the extra margarine under the skin, mostly over the breast.  I thought 1 Tbs of onion powder might be a bit much, but used it all, no problem.  My bird was a bit bigger, so took longer - an extra 30 or so minutes.  So I would be sure to use a thermometer to check for the correct internal temp.  The bird was gorgeous when I took it out, golden brown - then when I basted it  as directed,my mouth was watering, I had a hard time waiting the 30 minutes for the rest period!  Used the drippings with 1 cup low sodium and 3 Tbs. flour to make a gravy - this may be the best chicken gravy I have ever made.  Served with mashed potatoes and green beans - a simple and very comforting meal.  The crispy brown skin was to die for.  The breast was very tender and juicy.  An excellent recipe, I'm making a small turkey for Christmas and will use the onion powder and margarine for that and we'll see if it as good!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7301608.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, to all the naysayers, I say this: if you don't like margarine, use another oil. We used olive oil and ghee and grass fed butter on various occasions - turns out amazing. Second, cook it longer if it's raw; don't throw it out! Check the internal temp and cook until 165-180, not hard. We usually cook it about 1 hour 45-2 and that works. 

This is by far the juiciest and best whole chicken I've had - largely due to the celery inside. 

Also, another tip - if  you don't have celery, use rainbow chard inside and out. Add other veggies like potatoes and onion and carrots to the outside - fantastic.

text:
This is what I get for asking my 9 year old what he wants for dinner! “I want a turkey dinner mom!” He settled with chicken because I wasn’t going to try and defrost a turkey at 4:30 pm, I needed something quicker, and he settled with chicken and stuffing .  So, I did change a couple things, I ended up using stuffing and not celery, no margarine, and no onion powder. I put chicken stock for it to cook in and added the potatoes (it was heaven), seasoned it with garlic and herb seasoning (McCormick grill mates) inside and out, put slices of butter in the cavity, on top, and around the potatoes, threw some fresh rosemary to make the juices more fragrant (and I knew the potatoes would absorb the flavor as well) and threw a sprig on top! My chicken was 6 pounds, so I knew that it had to cook longer... when the juices ran clear I took it out and let it sit for about 20 minutes and sautéed some green beans while I waited... this has never happened to me, I ate so much that I made myself almost sick, THEN I KEPT EATING!!! I simply couldn’t stop, it was so good! Next time I will start earlier and leave it in for a bit longer, but other than that, I was so impressed with myself I almost cried (I have low confidence with cooking lol). I will be making this again! And with all the leftovers I’m going to make a soup for tonight! thank you!!

text:
This really was the best roast chicken I've ever made. The only things I changed were: 1) butter not margarine, added onion with the celery in cavity, used Mrs. Dash herb blend (instead of individual seasonings), and added 1.5 c water to pan before putting it in oven -- it gave just enough juice for a yummy gravy afterwards. Even the vegetarian among us enjoyed this meat!

text:
I didn’t finish reviewing and accidentally hit done on my phone. Docking off another star for Allrecipes’ app for not letting me review and edit before publishing! Anyway, I finally took out the chopped onions after the 1.25 hr cooking time was up and ended up changing to convection at 375 for the rest of the cooking time I needed. By the time this bird was fit for human consumption my husband and I were too hungry to bother basting and waiting the exorbitant 30 min of rest. Waiting 15 minutes was just fine while we finished up cooking the rest of our dinner. Yes this makes a juicy chicken but the recipe is flawed. And as at least one another reviewer mentioned, you need this to be cooked to 165 degrees F for poultry. No need to be 180 degrees.

text:
We all loved this.  I've made this twice and noticed that the more salt you use, the better it tastes (like deli rotis chicken).  The celery was a little chewy for my taste though.  I made this with a 5# bird as I couldn't find a smaller one at my local store. You just calculate it as 25 min per pound and it was done after 2.25 hours of cooking.  I think it's better to have a larger chicken anyway as it feeds more people and is more worth my time preparing and waiting for!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Found this while searching for cook times only.  While here, I read the reviews and decided many users need a cook time conversion.  Recipe calls for 3 pound chicken for 1h 15min at 350.  That is 75 min. divided by three, or 25 minutes per pound.  If you use a 4.5 pound chicken as another reviewer did, you will need to cook it for 25 X 4.5 = 112.5 min. or 1 hour and 52.5 minutes.

The three stars are for accurate cooking time.  The recipe itself is very basic.

text:
Wonderfully easy and tasty way to roast a chicken!  I followed the recipe as stated, but lacking onion powder, I substituted sliced onion, added to the celery in the cavity of the bird.  And like many other reviewers, I used butter instead of margarine, decreasing the amount by about 1/4. It was still exceptionally rich - true “finger-lickin’ good” chicken!  I will definitely make it again, but may use even less butter.  Since my chicken was almost 7 lbs., it took much longer to reach doneness, but was well worth the wait.  I roasted some carrots, potatoes, onions, celery and mushrooms in the same pan, and they were awesome, as was the gravy I made from the drippings.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
My husband and I had "gone off" supermarket chicken, but then I found an organic brand called FreeBird - no hormones, antibiotics, yada-yada. I wanted to try a simple roast to see what the chicken itself tasted like, and this recipe fit the bill because it didn't have a complicated sauce or too many aromatics.

WOWIE-ZOWIE is this a delicious recipe! I made it as written, except for butter because I never use margarine. If anyone has tried both, I'd love to know because if margarine is essential it would be worth it to me.

The flavor totally popped, and the meat was juicy and picked up the onion salt and celery without being overwhelming.
This is now my go-to recipe. (The chicken passed the test, too.)

userID:
25298136
Display Name:
rachelnorthrop
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time roasting a bird and it turned out well! 
I had a 5.5lb chicken and cooked it at 425 for 1hr 30 minutes which was perfect. It was incredibly juicy and flavorful and cooked through. I didn’t have a roasting pan (since I’ve never roasted a bird I’ve never thought to buy one) so I just used my Dutch oven with balled up tin foil at the bottom to lift the chicken up so it would roast instead of steam. 
I also didn’t have margarine and don’t buy it because I think it’s gross so I just used butter instead. I also stuffed a squeezed lemon rind into the cavity along with the celery and used Maldens sea salt instead of regular salt. The only other change I made was adding fresh chopped veggies 35 minutes before the chicken was done which wasn’t enough time-they were undercooked a bit. It turned out great, I’ve never had such juicy, flavorful white meat and it was just really delicious and flavorful! My husband loves having such a nice dinner on a week night. It made dinner for the 2 of it, 2 large Tupperware containers of leftovers with veggies and I still had a large breast and some other white meat left over for chicken salad or something. I also forgot to mention that I made gravy with the pan drippings which was very quick and made it that much better. The chickens were buy one get one free and I’ll definitely be repeating this recipe with the 2nd chicken!
Review:

5

text:
I have made this at least a dozen times, so I figured I owe praise to the recipe's creator.  This is the ONLY way I will ever roast chicken.  It turns out awesome every time, for real. The chicken turns out tender, juicy, and downright scrumptious.  I roast two at a time, in separate pans, and the turn the ample drippings into gravy (combining corn starch with 1/4 cup milk & adding this to the drippings/bringing to a boil).  I serve it with mashed potatoes and petite peas.   (Cook time on the two chickens is about 30 minutes longer than on one.)  Thank you for this amazing recipe!  I'm so very grateful!  Yum!

userID:
23250783
Display Name:
Ashlee

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5069737.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pay attention to your chicken's size!! I made this for my family and it was fantastic. The breast  wasn't even dry! Super moist. Follow the recipe basics. You should salt and pepper the chicken inside and out but you'll need more/less depending on the size/weight of your chicken. Same goes for the onion powder. I used a 5.3lb chicken so I had to use more seasoning than the recipe called for and baked for two hours, then pull out, cover and sit 30 minutes for the resting time. Still used one stalk of celery, but used more butter. Stick butter is great because you can cut cubes and throw it in the cavity and place them in the pan around the chicken. As far as prep before the oven, I put my chicken in a basic brine (salt water, 1/2 c. Kosher to 2qt water) for an hour in the fridge, rinsed off in cold water, patted dry with paper towels, let air dry in the fridge for another hour, then I splayed my chicken (to bake evenly, cut the skin along the thigh on each side where the legs connect to the body but don't sever, splaying the legs open so they lie flat on the pan), then seasoned everything. Don't forget your bake time will vary depending on chicken size! Approximately 20 minutes per pound or until breast temperature reads 180 degrees!

text:
I'll add another one of the "it was kind of weird how good this was" reviews.  I made minimal changes.  I did brine my chicken with a mixture of cold water, salt and lime juice for about 1 1/2 hours while I was getting the side dishes ready.  Other than that I followed the recipe exactly except to use butter (we don't own margarine) and add some garlic powder.    Please note the recipe says, "SEASON LIBERALLY".  Do not be light handed with your seasonings.  My bird was almost 4 lbs so I cooked it for 1 1/2 hours and then let it rest for the full 30 minutes.  It was perfect and extremely juicy and tasty.  My step daughter asked me how I made the chicken so good.  She also asked me to please not ever let her dad cook again.  (For some reason he was not nearly as amused as I was.)  I made her a plate and before I had finished fixing mine she was asking for more chicken.  She just went to bed to "sleep some of this food off".  It was really really good.

text:
Simple. Easy. A little messy trying to wrangle a wet chicken into a baking pan, rubbing margarine inside (and I am a real butter lover, but used Country Crock for this recipe) Salt, pepper... Shoved celery up in the nether region. 

My bird was a little over 6 pounds ( and wrapper said to roast 20 minutes per pound - about 2 hours+). Fortunately I checked mine after 1 hour, as I turned baking dish around. ( popped meat temp probe in and it was around 450 at that point).  There was no way that I could let it roast a whole other hour!  

I gave it 30 more minutes, and it was a little closer to 170, not ideal - but better than a raw chicken inside. 

Pulled it out of the oven, slapped some foil loosely on  top and allowed it to rest. 

Damned thing was cooked perfectly. Seasoned juices down below in baking dish screaming to be turned into  gravy. 

The amazing thing is, it tasted just like CHICKEN!!! 
Not bland, or boring - just pure, silky, juicy, tender chicken.

text:
Amazing!  I did throw my bird in a quick brine for about 6 hours, patted it dry before seasoning.  I added some ‘rotisserie chicken rub’ along with the salt and pepper.  Filled the cavity with lemon slices, butter, celery and green onion stalks. I think the trick is to only cook it to 165 and let it rest for 20-30 min. before carving. So tender and juicy!  My teenagers loved it so I’ll consider making 2 next time. I also made chicken noodle soup with the leftovers by slow slow simmering the carcass (I had to skim off a layer of butter after it sat in the fridge overnight, but so flavorful!)

text:
This recipe is suspiciously simple, so I assumed it would turn out like garbage. Bang-howdy, I was wrong! I'm not sure if it was the butter or the 30 minutes of resting time, but this was the juiciest, tastiest chicken I've made in years. For seasoning atop the chicken, I used parsley, rosemary, thyme (vital!), black pepper and a touch of seasoned salt.  Highly recommend this recipe as-is.

text:
I made this for my family and they absolutely loved it. I didn’t have any onion powder so this is what I did. I put the 3 tablespoons of butter in the cavity and I also added three small spoonfuls of Minced up garlic in a jar in the cavity and I sprinkled it with salt and garlic salt and then I melted a stick of butter and poured it all over the chicken and baked it for The hour and 15 minutes. It really came out so juicy

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made it I followed all directions except I didn't have onion powder, so I substituted finely diced onion in the cavity. It was so delicious I'm making it again. The white meat was very juicy. One other change I made was to rub a little of the salt and butter (not margarine) directly onto the flesh. I did this by cutting the membrane that attaches the skin to the breast meat and separating it with my hands (the first slit is made at the bottom cavity, not at the neck). It's an old habit I got into and did it without thinking both times.

I had a 4lb. chicken and added another 1/2 hour @ 375 but I still think I'd like it cooked a little more.  It registered 180 so it was done but I like my chicken to fall off the bone.  Butter was a wonderful idea.  I used a cup of chicken broth and 1 1/2 Tbsp. of cornstarch to make gravy.  There was really only the butter drippings but the gravy was delish. I will make this again.

text:
Wow! It really is juicy!! This chicken was the best I’ve ever coked! I often pick up a rotisserie chicken from the store, but I’ll be cooking my own more now. It’s much cheaper. My son loved it too, and went back for more! He’s 17, but not a big eater usually. The only thing I changed, was using garlic powder instead of onion powder, because that’s what I had. I even made delicious gravy, and didn’t need to season it all. I did have to cook the bird longer than 1 1/2 hours, but ovens vary. Yum!!

text:
Wow, what a strange and wonderful recipe!  So simple, a little odd that celery goes in the chicken.  But, amazingly great reviews from my family - super moist, very flavorful.  Chicken was not high on our dinner preferences, but this recipe moved it up near the top!  Next time, I'll experiment with some other spices.  WAY better than rotissierie chicken!  For those reviews where the bird wasn't cooked or took too long... the recipe calls for a 3 pound chicken, but you should ALWAYS cook poultry using a thermometer to ensure it's cooked properly -- cooking times vary greatly depending on the size of the chicken and how your oven heats & cooks -- this is not the fault of the person who posted the recipe.

userID:
7737426
Display Name:
Manny
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
36
favoritesCount:
152
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5932401.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
400 degree oven. check w temp gauge after 1 hr. Broil for 4-5 minutes after basting. Sub 1/2 cup butter. Whole onion quarter, 2 whole jalapeños, 2 tbs grated ginger, 6 whole cloves, 5-6 large carrots peeled and split, pound of Brussels sprouts, 1/2 lemon 1/4” slices under skin, limes quarter and stuff cavity. Add 1/2 onion couple carrot and garlic in cavity. Butter and season in and out. Olive oil pan and outside veggies. Ginger under skin and on top w butter. Seasonings salt, pepper, garlic salt, rosemary, cumin. Pull at 165 degrees at breast and thigh. Rest 30 minutes under foil. Turns out juicy, perfectly browned, and so flavorful.

country:

text:
This was so good!  Only problem was it was not quite done in allotted time, but am sure it is my oven.  It browned evenly and was so succulent.  The only thing we did different was to add garlic, onion, carrots and lemon in cavity.   Yum!  We made a side dish of Stove Top stuffing.  After we get all the meat we can get, then we boil tne carcass to get bits of chicken off.  Then we use the chicken bits, the water we boil it in, the veggies minus lemon, and leftover dressing and bring to boil again and add in noodles until done.  This so good!  I use Amish noodles, but am sure any wide noodle would do.

Display Name:
MeowBoops

country:

text:
Here is my experience. I followed directions exactly (used butter instead of margarine). The recipe doesn't say to flip the chicken over halfway so I didn't do that. So, I baked the chicken for 1 hour and 15 minutes. I checked it and it wasn't even close to being done. I added 30 minutes to the timer and checked it again. It still wasn't done according to my thermometer. I added another 30 minutes to the timer. It finally browned to my liking so I took it out, covered it, and let it rest for 20 minutes. When I started cutting into it, I noticed pink juices coming out. Turns out, the bottom of the chicken was still slightly undercooked. When I checked with the meat therm originally, I must have poked near the surface or somewhere really hot because the thermometer showed 165 (I know recipe says 180 but I thought that was too done). Anyways, I have 1/4 of the chicken cut up and pulled apart so I flipped what was left of the carcass and put it back in with the undercooked side up. I set the timer for another 30 minutes. Hopefully it won't dry out the bird. 

1. I think the cook time on the recipe is wrong
2. I think you should flip the bird halfway through the total time (maybe after 1.5 hours?)
3. The simplicity of the seasonings makes this recipe really easy and it actually tastes really good (I picked off a few pieces from the cooked side of the bird)

I will try this again with another whole chicken sometime and update my review.

text:
This was the first whole chicken that I had ever roasted so I was a little nervous about it. There was no reason to be nervous at all! It was amazing!! My family loved it! The only change that I made was that my bird was about twice the size of the suggested size in the recipe so I doubled the ingredients and added time to the bake time to ensure that it was cooked all of the way through. I also used a meat thermometer (didn’t want to eat undercooked chicken). I also basted it about every 20-30 minutes while it cooked. So simple and so delish!! This will definitely be one of my go to recipes for comfort food.

text:
Excellent!  First time i can honestly say my roasted chicken turned out great.  I had a large 6 pound chicken so i used double the ingredients but super easy and flavorful.  I also used butter instead of margarine which i rubbed under the breast skin, too.   My 6 lb. chicken took a little more than 2 hours.  Super juicy and lots of pan juices for gravy.  I always thought you needed some water or broth to prevent drying but not true.  This was moist and beautifully browned. I roasted this in my deep dish copper chef pan which is great from oven to stove top to make gravy.  Dont skimp on the onion powder as it is the sole seasoning that gives the chicken flavor.

userID:

Display Name:
Becky Kutner
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5387774.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy recipe, made a few changes based on some recommendations but have no doubt the original would have been wonderful as well.

In addition to the celery I put a clove of garlic and quarter of an onion in the chicken. Under the skin I added some chopped garlic and herb de provence and instead of margarine I used Earth Balance to make it a kosher friendly meal. I did use the onion powder on the outside as well as the original calls for.

About 30 minutes before the chicken was due to be done I added some chopped carrots, mushrooms, yellow squash, and potatoes that I tossed with olive oil, rosemary and thyme. Be careful this did increase the cooking time of the chicken a little so might add them 45 minutes before the chicken is due to be done next time, and basted a few times during that period. 

Came out really tasty and the veggies completed the meal.
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
22680278
Display Name:
Cucina Testarossa!
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this simple, yet superb, dish on 3 occasions and the chicken comes out juicy and lip-smacking delicious each time. I've tried other  (famous) preparations, which have been excellent, but I keep going back to this one, which gets the most raves from my family.

Couple comments: I check roasting time with the instant thermometer, and let the bird rest for 10 min before serving. Which makes it even more juicy! 

This recipe totally stands on its own, but here are a few SLIGHT variations to consider: I've used only onion powder and another time, I also added garlic powder, which I recommend. But it's awesome with just the onion powder if  you don't want to add garlic. I combine raw onion with the celery in the cavity (along with the other listed ingredients) and smear 2 TBS salted butter (I used Irish butter, but I'm sure other types will be good) underneath the skin on top, in addition to putting butter in the cavity. It does not make it too buttery - at least for us! About 45 min into cooking (3 or so lb bird), I add onion, celery and carrots to the roasting pan. By then, delicious jus has pooled in the bottom of the pan. I also add a cup of chicken stock (store bought) at that time to increase the amount of jus, since my family loves it so much. 

I usually serve the chicken with rice (potatoes are great too), au jus and veggies from the pan. I encourage you to try this dish, you'll love it!

text:
I made this recipe on 10/28/17. I made it on Saturday evening for Sunday dinner. I got two sanders farm whole young chicken at Walnart meat center on Thursday 10/27/17 for 0.97 cents a pound. I pay $10.30 for two pack. I wasn't sure if I needed get roasting chicken or  whole young chicken. I decided get two young chicken. I only cook one as trial test because I am cook other one on vertern day for my man who is a veteran. I follow recipe to t except I didnt use twine. This chicken was juicy favoriteful and delclious. Only thing I didnt like is didnt say was and dry bird . clean the chicken thoroughly and remove all content from the activity. Pat dry the chicken with paper towel. This chicken was so good. The hardestbpart was getting chicken neck ,giblets, heart out of chicken. It was not in a bag like butterball turkey. I had to reach inside and get the giblets neck and heart out.  Some cooks especially inexperienced ones might not known to take the heart giblets, and neck out if the bird. Because NY bird was 5 pounds I cook it at 350  for 2hours and twenty minutes. I cook at 2 hours and fifteen minutes.vThen I let it broil for 5 minutes. After hour at 350 I  basted it every  twenty minutes with juices from pan.

text:
It was ok. Not as much flavor as I like. I think the trick to this recipe is to first ...check the weight of the bird you are cooking. 2nd...make sure you use a meat thermometer to test for doneness. Mine was not done after the hour and fifteen including another 30 minutes of rest time. I had to put mine back in for another half hour. I used my meat thermometer both times...turned out way better after an additional 30 minutes in the oven at 350 degrees.

text:
I, like many other non-believers, saw this recipe and thought.........there's no way this can have close to 5 stars and rave reviews w/ so few ingredients.  Call me a fool & go ahead & kick my a@*!  This is the juiciest chicken I've ever had! My only mistake is that I didn't sprinkle enough of the spices on there.  I guess I got scared I'd make it too salty or peppery.  That was my fault though, and in no way did it affect how juicy the chicken came out.  I used butter because it's all I had.  My mother was sucking the meat off the bone!   When it was time to put the leftover chicken away, I picked it up and the bone from the wing just fell right out!  That's how moist and juicy this came out!  I will definitely be making this again in the future.

text:
I too, was looking for an easy and fast way to roast a whole chicken. Googled it, and this was the one I made! Simple and oh so yummy. I do change the seasoning a little each time. ex; I put an onion inside the bird with celery and or whole carrots. I have also put whole garlic inside the bird when baking as well. The things I do not change are the salt, pepper and butter! I use as directed every time. I believe these are the essential seasons and way to keep the bird the most moist! I also, typically use a larger bird too. I am feeding a 15 year old football player! Just try it one time, I'm sure it will be your go to as well!

userID:
731723
Display Name:
SZYQ1
isPro:
False
followersCount:
61
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
639
favoritesCount:
3048
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4049308.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Typically, I prefer more seasoning/herbs when roasting chicken, but this worked very well for wanting to use the remaining chicken in other dishes requiring different and more seasoning. Used my gas grill rotisserie option to make this instead of firing up the oven and it came out very juicy and tender, just enough flavor too. Skin was not crisp though. Perhaps it would have been using the oven method. Followed all recipe steps, but tied the legs and wings for the rotisserie. If you choose to make it on rotisserie, just follow the manufacturer instructions to do so. You'll need indirect heat and put a pan underneath to catch the drippings for sure! The whole chicken I had was almost 6 lb and took about 2.5 hours to cook through. Used a meat thermometer and removed chicken at 165 degrees, placed on platter and tented with foil to let rest for 10 minutes before carving/slicing. Will be making this again! Thanks for sharing your grandmother's recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
Very juicy, and the house smelled awesome while it was cooking, but ultimately lacking in flavor.  Definitely an easy way of cooking a chicken.  I might try this again, with a mix of additional spices, making sure to fully lift the skin and distribute them under the skin across the whole chicken.  I only lifted the skin in a few places, as the instructions didn't really say to do that.  Also, I noticed some reviewers said it wasn't done in the stated time -- make sure you account for the size of the bird, and use a meat thermometer.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a few times now.  This recipe is great at producing a juicy chicken, but I'm not too crazy about the onion powder flavor.  I think that the butter and celery are really the only ingredients that matter with regard to juiciness, so I've been experimenting with different dry rubs.  Right now my dry rub is equal parts onion powder, garlic powder, paprika, salt, and pepper, and a few drops of liquid smoke.  Also, I recently tried doing a chicken with butter dolloped on one half and margarine dolloped on the other half, and the butter half was WAY crispier, so I think I'll stick with butter only from here on out.  Also, it helps if you brine the chicken.
Review:

userID:
13761660
Display Name:
abing
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6045687.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We just made this a couple nights ago and it turned out fantastic !! We had a 5lb chicken so had to up the time to accommodate since it's listed for a 3lb chicken. We guessed at 2 hours and 5 minutes for our 5 pounder. It came out a tad dry but I believe that was our fault for over cooking. We checked it around an hour and 50 minutes and the temp was right at 160 so I think if we had turned off the oven and let it sit in there for about 10 minutes then taken it out and let it rest (it still cooks a bit after removing from oven) then it would have been spot on perfect. We are going to try that again next time which will actually be tonight, it was that yummy ! We followed the recipe as written...well to be 100% fair we do not own nor everrrr use margarine and I can't have butter so we used Melt for the margarine. It's a coconut and palm oil type "butter".  We put some veggies (carrots, turnip root, brussel sprouts, and onion) on the bottom of the pan to roast under the chicken. SO SO GOOD ! The flavor is phenomenal and the cooking method is great if you get the time right and keep a check on the internal temp. This one and the other recipe we have used from here (Roast Sticky Chicken Rotisserie Style) a couple times are definite keepers, we plan on trying this recipe with the other ones cooking method (lower temp for longer) and see how it turns out. Love them both but this one is favorite so far !

text:
By far the best (and easiest) roast chicken I've ever made! Although at this temp (350) I find it takes closer to 2 hours to cook (I baste at 1hr15min then cook for another 45 mins at least). I use butter instead of margarine, and onion granules instead of powder. I also sometimes chop up a few onions, splash them with olive oil, salt and pepper, and throw them in the roasting pan. They basically carmelize and add even more delicious sweet onion flavor to the bird!

text:
This was easy to make. Yes, it was moist but no wonder,  it called for a whole stick of marg (i used butter). Certainly was bland for all the seasoning and veggies - i added half-dozen small green onions in cavity with celery and sprinkled garlic powder everywhere. Subtle but bland. Was hoping for Pow! Perhaps all that marg/butter overpowered. Lastly, do not recommend covering for 30 mins after roasting to 180 degrees - the dern thing is ready to eat at 180; consequently, when trying to slice our chicken it was just in shreds. Leg and wing bones pulled away from the overcooked meat. Skin, of course, was like rubber. A real disappointment - the bird smelled delicious while roasting.

text:
This is the BEST chicken recipe I've ever tasted and is now the only way I prepare chicken. I made a few changes, like I eye the butter- I put enough to coat the inside and put dollops on top because it creates a crispier skin. I also put a HELLA amount of garlic powder/garlic salt. It makes a salty (though not so salty its unedible) skin on the chicken and it's just delicious (if you like salty foods or fried chicken you'll love it). Putting butter inside also makes the meat really tender and juicy and man this chicken is just too perfect.

userID:
504001
Display Name:
TASHA156

27

697

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6625208.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe exactly as written and I recommend making it exactly as written the 1st time (using margarine and not butter, celery and not other things and 25 minutes a pound in the oven), after you are comfortable with the recipe then adjust to your personal taste, i.e. I prefer garlic powder to onion powder.  The margarine keeps the chicken juicier than butter does (I tried both) and for those who said the chicken was underdone but used larger birds...simple math, 3 lb bird was an hour and 15 minutes, if you are using a larger bird it will need more time...the math is simple, the recipe calls for 25 minute a pound so adjust your time according to how big your chicken is) and after resting double check for doneness with a meat thermometer and juices running clear.  You won't be disappointed with this recipe as long as you follow the recipe as written...it's as classic a roast chicken recipe as you can get and tried and true...I use this recipe every time...Love love love it.

text:
The internal temperature listed in this recipe is incorrect. It should be 165 degrees not 180 degrees.   If you cook it to 180, it will be over done and dry.  Also at a temperature of 350 to skin won't get crispy enough.  It's a basic recipe, but it seems to have a few errors.

text:
Just made it and it was juicy and delicious.  Even my husband liked it when he prefers dry meats.  Followed the recipe, but had to double it because I could only find a 6 pound chicken even though I preferred a 3 pound one since it was only for my husband and me.  Since it was a 6 pound chicken, I also doubled the cooking time.  But basically  it took that 2 1/2 hours for the internal temperature of 180 degrees which is the key to having it well cooked. After the chicken cooked for a hour or less,  I did put about 1/2 cup each of both sliced carrots and onions around the chicken with a little water to help cook them.  This way I had my cooked vegetables and it made the gravy tasty as well.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Could only find a 5.5 lb chicken at the market. I brined it in saltwater for 1 hr then seasoned it with salt and pepper all around then the 1/2c butter mixed with chopped garlic. I filled the cavity with rosemary sprigs, 1 carrot and 1/4 onion. I followed the instructions on the allrecipes "best roasted chicken tips and times" ( http://dish.allrecipes.com/the-best-roast-chicken/ ) so I baked it at 425 for 15 min breast side up then turned the heat down to 350 for the remaining baking time and turned it breast down. 15 min before it was done, I turned it back, breast side up and turned the heat up to 450 to brown the skin. Turned out amazing and moist!! Very happy with this recipe.

text:
This was really tasty!  Due to our scheduling (being away from home for a few hours), I put the 6-lb chicken in the crockpot and cooked it on High.  In addition to the celery and seasonings in the cavity, I also put in a few cloves of garlic, since we love garlic.  I used butter instead of margarine since that's what I had, but put in a little less than called for - just under half a stick of butter.
You know the chicken is good when you ask your "selective" child if she's eaten her corn yet and she says, "No, Mom, but this chicken is so good!"  After she ate all her food, she then had seconds of the chicken!  
Thanks for a great recipe.  I am looking forward to trying it again with the suggested cooking method of roasting.

text:
I loved this! I mixed it with the Moist Garlic Roasted Chicken recipe and used all the ingredients in both as well as some additional ones. I popped it in a pyrex dish (my roasting pan didn't fit in the European oven!) and added all the ingredients + some extra spices (chopped onion, garlic salt, garlic cloves inside/outside, lemons everywhere, provincial herbs, butter) and then brushed the liquid over (no baste tool in Spain!) once and it was still perfect. Near the end I covered it loosely in aluminium, turned off the oven and let it rest in there for a while as I prepared the other food. It came out soo juicy, flavorful, delicious, it didn't even need something to dip in because it's so yummy.  Would make again definitely!

text:
I've never submitted a review before, but it's a must with this wonderfully tasty, and extremely simple recipe. My family raves about it every single time. Please, please make it at least once, exactly as the recipe appears. You'll see why we say this, and what we're all raving  about. This recipe is perfect as is. It's so flavorful and juicy. 
Even the worst cooks, including myself, can't go wrong with this recipe. It seems unbelievable that these few simple ingredients can produce such outstanding results, but they do. 
Your kitchen will smell like a dream!
 Oh, I do add one tiny thing. I toss an onion into the chicken cavity with the celery, but it's not a must. Just something to honor my own moms memory. She never cooked any whole bird without an onion and celery inside. Thank you so much for this amazing recipe! It's the one thing I cook that comes out great hands down. ENJOY IT!

Love this simple recipe.  I don't understand how it turns out so juicy, but it does. The only thing I changed is after taking it out of the  oven I don't baste it with the drippings or cover it with foil. I did do that the first time but I lost the crispy skin.

text:
This is a really good basic recipe. The only changes I sometimes make is to use butter instead of margarine and I mix in a tablespoon of garlic powder into the butter and rub the chicken with it.  I also add fresh garlic to the cavity and sometimes also lemon quarters. My cooking time is longer than the hour and fifteen minutes. Use a thermometer to make sure the chicken is adequately cooked.

text:
This recipe - specifically the trick with the margarine (albeit I used butter) - made this the most moist chicken I've ever had.  It's incredibly moist; surprisingly so.  I covered it with foil for an hour and baked the last 15-min uncovered.  After resting for 30 min, it was apparent upon carving to the base of the breast that it could have stood another 10 minutes in the oven.  Every oven's different, so no worries there.

Tom Burke

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I didn't have a whole chicken. Thought I did but found out after the chicken thawed that it was 10 pieces of thighs frozen together that took on the appearance of a whole freak'in chicken! Anyway. So here's what I did. I stuck to the recipe and only added chicken base water at bottom. Salt and peppered ckn both sides and then brushed some margarine on. Put a small rack in the middle of the pan (enough to fit two pieces on top) then added the ingredients on the bottom. Filled the pan with the ckn pieces and closed the lid for baking. After an hour, removed the lid and browned the top of ckn for about 15 minutes, as it took. Turned off oven and closed lid again and stayed in oven till put on table. Best  recipe this side of the Mississippi !!

userID:

Display Name:
Kerri Adams

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3654045.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing as is!!! I have made this over 20 times and it is great.  The things I did do, I did for personal taste - I add a small cup of chicken  broth to the bottom of the roasting pan. I also add more butter and I baste the chicken with it as it cooks. I  cook the chicken longer and I turn the oven up to 400 so the skin gets extra crispy.  Finally, after everyone has eaten. I take whatever is left throw it in a big pot with broth and water (just enough water to cover the chicken)  I boil  it down on medium heat until it literally falls apart. I then, drain the pot and I save the liquid. It makes the BEST chicken stock ever!!!  I freeze it in Tupperware and I use it for future recipe's. The left over chicken I pick apart and I save that as well.  The stock from this chicken adds a depth of flavor to any recipes.  Thank you for posting this recipe. It's my go-to chicken and I always get rave reviews. So again, thank you!!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sounded too easy to be very special....but trusted the reviews and am so glad I did! DELICIOUS and so moist and tender.
Used onion in bird instead of celery and garlic powder instead of onion powder. 3 T Butter in bird, 2 T canola margerine rubbed on entire outside of bird, heavily seasoned with salt, pepper, paprika and garlic powder. Cooked 5# chicken, breast side down on foil lined baking sheet at 350 degrees for 2 hours, uncovered. Rested 30 minutes.
Made best gravy ever with pan drippings, 2 T flour and 1 cup milk,  Skimmed fat off . Mmmmmm!
Hubby loved it. Now will be my forever basic chicken recipe. Thanks so much for sharing!!

text:
I made this as written. Pretty darn good. i baked it uncovered for the stated time & my thermometer read 180 deg. i took it out of the oven & let it rest for 30 min as stated. However when i went to plate the chicken i noticed some blood running out. I put it back in the oven in a covered roasting pan for an additional 30 min. Came out great! Still very juicy. The gravy I made from the juices was Awesome!!! I will make this again but will cook it longer. Like they say, oven temps vary. Still  good!!!!

text:
I love this recipe and have made it many times. It is the juiciest tastiest chicken. For a one pot meal dice 1/2 onion, 2 carrot sticks, 2 celery stalks and 5 large new potatoes. Place at the bottom of the baking dish underneath the chicken. Add 1/2 cup chicken broth before putting in the oven to cook. You can thicken the broth at the bottom of the pan later for gravy. So delicious!

text:
Very good tasting roasted chicken. I needed to make some chicken thighs and wanted something easy and simple. This isn't anything fancy, but it's a simple dish that you can spice up on your own. 

So, I had 8 chicken thighs that I seasoned on both sides with the addition of garlic powder. Started skin side down and flipped it halfway. Started at 350 degrees. When I flipped it, I raised it to 375. Baked for an hour.  When I just need to bake chicken without thinking about it, I will do this again.

Followed recipe exact with these additions:
 - placed butter in cavity as required and then push left over butter from the 1 stick under the skin in breast and thighs.
- replace or augment celery with a whole orange cut in wedges and placed in cavity
- use onion powder and garlic powder as called for. 
- Placed chicken in a Le  Creuset Pot breast side down on top of carrots 
-add mushrooms and small potatoes and/or thin sliced sweet potatoes to the pot around the chicken.

userID:
14871733
Display Name:
Dale Erspamer
isPro:

followersCount:
1

8

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1794089.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i learned how to make this chicken from my grandmother over 50 years ago.  i disagree, however, with the temperature of the done bird.  Using a thermometer, the bird is done @165 degrees f.  Check both the breast and thigh the proper temp.  if you want, wrap an aluminum can in tin foil and place into cavity  of the bird, open side out,  and balance on end in the oven.  This helps the thighs reach temp at the same time of the breasts.  This method speeds cooking time as well, so start checking temps at 45 minutes.
Review:

text:
Short story: Super easy prep, delicious chicken, took longer to cook than recipe stated.  

I made this yesterday.

I picked up a new puppy Saturday and am home all week with her. I enjoy cooking and make an effort to do it when I am home and free of obligations. I wanted a hearty recipe that I wouldn't cook normally (ie. cooking time is super long - so I could never cook this on a normal night when I get home at 5:30 or so). Watching a puppy while cooking, something easy on prep was ideal.  

This was perfect! The prep is (as you can see from the recipe) super easy! The chicken was juicy and delicious.  

As one other reviewer noted, it did take much longer than 1 hour and 15 minutes for me to get to 180 degrees.  Maybe my chicken was larger (or possibly extra cold from the grocery store since I had picked it up earlier)?  Either way, I would guess it ended up in the oven for an hour and 45 minutes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3992093.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! Seasoned with the salt, pepper, onion powder and added a little dusting of zenders chicken seasoning because we love it so much. Used the celery and added half a mandarin orange and chopped elephant garlic to the cavity along with the butter. Of course seasoned the inside. Placed slices of elephant garlic under the skin in several places. Seasoned and rubbed butter under the skin as well. Started by cooking it at 450 for 15 minutes and then reduced heat to 350 and cooked for 2 hours and 15 minutes. Then removed from oven and covered w foil for maybe 10 minutes. It was fabulous! Whole chickens and myself have not really ever gotten along but I am confident this is the recipe I will stick with. Thank you so much for giving me a starting point. My family cleaned their plates and asked for more!

text:
My own fault it didn't receive 5 stars. I picked up a whole chicken, which I have never cooked first, then found the recipe. My chicken was nearly 5.5 pounds. I followed the directions but wanted a one pan meal so I added some cut sweet potatoes, a couple of wedged onions and 6 ears of corn to the bottom, put the chicken on top and cooked for a total of 2 hours to reach 180 internal temp. Next time I will 1) buy the right sized bird or cover with foil for the last half of cooking. 2) put the corn on the bottom of the chicken and surround chicken with sweet potatoes. Everything was delish!

text:
A perfect simple roasted chicken that comes out exceptionally tended on the inside while still crisp on the outside.  The recipe calls for a very small chicken.  So, if you are following the recipe timing exactly, get a chicken in the right size, or it will be under cooked.  Adjusting the timing would work for a larger bird, of course, but I'll leave math to the mathematicians.

text:
When I read the recipe and reviews I was a little skeptical that this was going to be the greatest chicken ever. But indeed it was! I'm still amazed how little ingredients can be so tasty. I followed the recipe as it is (had to use garlic powder instead because I didn't have the onion one, and butter because I never have margarine) and had to resist the temptation to add herbs. I had some extra celery I couldn't fit in the cavity so I threw them around and they were to die for! Cooked it longer until it was golden brown. Hubby and I loved it, and this recipe it's definitely a keeper.

text:
The smell will drive you crazy. 
This is one of those meals you prepare when you want everyone nice and hungry upon serving.  It smells so good that I couldn't concentrate on much other than the chicken!  It is as good as everyone says.  I had the same issue with cooking time as another reviewer.  I oven baked it exactly as stated, but after one hour and 15 minutes,  my chicken was still bloody inside and the temp was 140.  I used a large baking pan.  Next time I'll use my smaller Dutch Oven to see if that makes a difference.   My advice is to judge cooking time by the stated internal temperature.  But, the recipe is definitely a very easy 5 star recipe!

text:
People, this is a great starter if you have never roasted a chicken.  I just came in to check oven timing. I put onions and celery in the cavity for flavor while roasting and then discard. I put butter and minced garlic under the skin, top the bird with onion powder, garlic powder, and parsley flakes. I use tin foil on the wings. I spray my roasting pan with butter spray. Add carrots and potatoes half way through cooking time. One pot meal. Easy Peasy.

text:
I have made many many roasted chickens over the years for several occasions and you can doll them up in very creative ways. This is a simple yet very good recipe. My go to base is the same and you can just change it up depending on your mood. I have stuffed the cavity with everything from various fruits and veges plus spices. Tonight I did an orange, rosemary, real butter, and fresh garlic with sea salt and pepper, with real butter. It turned out amazing as always. I think one of the best things you can do is add some of your spices on top between the skin and breast with butter for that extra flavor. Serve with potatoes and steamed broccoli or asparagus.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Incredibly tender, juicy and delicious! I made just as is with two necessary exceptions: first, I was cooking a 5.5 lb. chicken, so I added 1 hour to the cooking time. And second, the recipe calls for cooking this to an internal temperature of 180 and that is actually going to overcook your chicken. 165 is perfectly and safely cooked, so check and take your chicken out when the thermometer reads about 160 degrees. Then let the chicken rest for about 20 minutes and it will finish cooking to a perfect 165.

text:
I cannot believe I have not rated this. My go to, can't wait to eat comfort food that is versatile.the first time I followed the recipe exactly and fell in love. After that I have played with it but not much!  I don't cook poultry by time, instead I use a thermometer. A ooking spray on the outside, butter in the cavity, few things I few things i have tried was starting it in the crockpot and then towards the end transferring everything to a roasting pan. That makes delicious moist chicken. I have also just wadded up foil balls, sPrayed it with cam not stingy with butter. It really allows the skin to crisp. The flavor is delicious, the chicken is moist and the simple veggies just make the dish.

We are a family of three. One 5 lb birds provides us, usually four meals.  After we eat on the first day i boil the carcass and make stock. Day one is leftovers. Day two is leftover creamy chicken enchiladas. Day three is chicken salad sandwiches and finally, day four is Zuppa Tuscano with Italian toast.

text:
I made this the other night with homeade stuffing, mashed potatos, gravy and green beans...and it was a HUGE hit... I followed the recipe and a few reviews.. Placed marg under the skin and added lemon pepper seasoning.  I used Adobo instead of and powders. I did 15 minutes to start at 450 degrees then right before it was done I hit it again at 450 to get it crispy.  I think letting it sit under the foil tent is where most of the magic happens.  I invited my friend to eat over and she started eating and said my dinner was so good she could make love to it...lol.  She also said the chicken was much better then what you can get at the store and pay $5 for said she would pay $20.00 for this one all day long.  I gave some to the neighbor she said that chicken was HELLOFA-- I said what does that mean she said  good.  This is a keeper and I am so glad I found this recipe!

text:
I pretty much followed the recipe except used more seasoning with some added garlic powder.  I also tossed in some carrot cut in strips and parsnips cut in strips with onions.  The vegetables actually tasted better then the chicken.  Next time I will season under the skin.  We take off the skin to eat it and the meat had little flavor.  I also basted the recipe during the cooking process.  The vegetables came out very flavorful and caramelized.  I will play around with the recipe to make it a five star.  Definitely would try it again.

This is the BOMB !  My husband does'nt like baked chicken, trust me I've tried MANY, MANY different way's. We had it for dinner last night, not only did he ask for second's, he asked that I send it in his lunch today!  Then to beat all, he's asked that I make this one of our regular's ! Any of you with extremly picky eater's have got to try this one.  I did follow some of the other's comment's. I did'nt have onion powder, so I minced a small onion, I also minced 3 large cloves of garlic.  Then I stuffed the outside seasoning & the butter under the skin.  I also basted every 15 minutes. This recipe is fantastic as is, but also many options to play with different seasonings. I can't wait to try using lemon peper.  Thank's so much for sharing this!

text:
My first roast chicken and it was delicious! Thank you. I did tweak it a bit but only because I was trying to use up what I already had on-hand. Butter instead of margarine, and threw in half an onion and a half of lemon. I seasoned with garlic salt and pepper and a dash of Herbes de Provence inside. The end product came out juicy, with a crispy skin on top and about 3/4 inch of liquid on the bottom - it made an awesome gravy. I put the chicken up on two onion slices as I'd read in a cpl reviews, but he slid off at some point. Definitely be sure to season to your taste preference and don't forget the onion powder (or garlic salt) on the inside! The house smelled delicious as this roasted. I had a chicken that was just over 4lbs and added an extra 35mins to the oven time- came out perfectly. I'm going to try this recipe as written next time. Thanks again!

Wow, this is the first time I ever made roasted chicken because it always seemed so complex, but it is seriously one of the easiest meals I've ever made!!  This recipe is delicious as is, but I added some lemon and garlic to the cavity along with the celery.  My chicken came out super moist and tender and we are putting this on our regular dinner menu from now on!!  I did have to increase the baking time on mine though because mine was still a little pink around the bones when I baked it for the stated 1 hr 15 minutes.  I needed at least 1 hr 30 min with my oven.  I also like to use the leftover carcass for chicken broth.  This is the meal that just keeps on giving!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is similar to a recipe I've used with consistent, awesome results.  The chicken is always juicy!  Brine it with a brining recipe of your choice if you have time, and it will be even more tasty & juicy!  I always season the bird inside and out with salt, pepper, garlic powder, and onion powder. Then I put a medium peeled & quartered onion, several whole peeled cloves of garlic, celery, carrots, and rosemary in the cavity as well.  Adding the fresh veggies & herbs amps up the flavor.  (If you like spicy, add some whole jalepenos!) Always test with a thermometer in the thickest part of the thigh and breast to make sure it has reached a safe internal temp of 180.

The recipe is true to its name- juicy. First time I've done a roasted chicken and it came out with crispy skin so the family loved it. Along with the celery and butter, I used Italian seasoning under and over the skin. Including cut vegetables halfway through the cooking time makes a complete meal. I placed the chicken on top of cut onion rings then added carrots, parsnips and zucchini later.

text:
I did add paprika to my rub, and lemon and onion in the cavity...but to those saying it wasn't cooked thoroughly, I would say I have never had luck with roasts/whole poultry cooking times.  A recipe is a general guess...Want to be sure it's cooked?  Use a meat thermometer.  I use one with a probe in the center of the breast, temperature set to 160 on monitor outside the oven.  When it beeps, it's done!
