https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1127644.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've roasted many a chicken and must say this simple recipe made a perfect chicken for us. I used a 4 lb chicken and still followed her directions exactly. The skin was crispy and the meat was tender and juicy. And this is what I learned from it:
1. I'd always basted, basting a chicken may leave the skin soft rather than crispy. 
2. And I'd always spread herbed butter beneath the surface of the skin (which I never enjoyed doing in the first place) and I think perhaps pulling the skin away in that manner may leave the meat vulnerable to drying out.
The onion powder creates a nice fragrant chicken, though some may like garlic powder or the like.
I highly recommend.
Review:

5

text:
Definitely juicy! Like many other reviewers, I thought the ingredient list was way too simple to yield such glowing reviews. And, like many other reviewers, I was pleasantly surprised. I used half butter, half margarine, because that's what I had in my refrigerator. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. Cook time was a bit longer for me, but not substantially. The drippings made delicious gravy. I may use less margarine and swap in some garlic powder for the onion powder next time, but this recipe is definitely a keeper and one that I can add to my kids' list of dinners they can help prepare. Thanks for sharing!

text:
This chicken was amazing!  I will definitely be making it again and again!!  I didn't have a large roasting pan so I just bought a large chicken breast (with bone and skin) and roasted it.  I also added a touch of garlic and thyme (as others had suggested combining the moist garlic chicken recipe).  I didn't add any lemon, but may try that in the future.  This chicken was super moist and extremely flavorful.  It was already late in the evening, so I didn't do the last step (covering with foil and letting it rest for 30 minutes), and it was still great!

text:
I made this for our family's Thanksgiving lunch (we're not big turkey fans).. my first time EVER roasting a chicken much less for a big holiday.. and it was so DELICIOUS!!!!  My family was very impressed and my dad who is very picky said the spices were really pleasing to him. I can't remember what all I added but definitely onion and garlic powder, maybe some thyme. I stuffed it with quartered lemons and spices and brushed an herb/butter mixture on top in addition to the dollops placed all around. I also turned it breast side up for the last hour and it gave it an all-around nice golden brown color. The meat was soo tender and buttery! I don't remember the last time I had chicken that good. I wish the skin was maybe a little bit crispier like the way my mom makes it but that is just a preference. Also, I threw the giblets and pan drippings in with some flour and chicken stock -- it made an amazingly thick, rich gravy that I absolutely devoured!!! Way better than the packet stuff. Thank you for making me a star cook at my first attempt!!!!! I am just thrilled with this recipe!

This has always turned out so good, every time, no fail. This is a no fail chicken recipe. Very delicious!  My house smelled so good while it was baking I could hardly stand it.  In addition to recipe listed I added a couple of cloves of garlic to cavity and a few pieces of lemon.  I also put slices of onion under the bird to keep it from sticking.  Chicken was super tender and juicy.  Made fabulous gravy from pan juices and the stock I made the next day was excellent!!!  I followed cooking times listed for 3 pd bird.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2368134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Based on how tender the chicken was I would rate it a 5.  It was also fairly easy to make and everyone really liked it. I am giving it a 4, because I think it is an awful lot of butter! And, most of it just sits on the bottom. I also thought I used a pretty large pan, but butter still managed to get out of the pan and burn to the oven. (Use a stable pan with fairly high sides). I did cook it an extra 15 minutes and most of it was cooked, but their was still some pink liquid when cutting.  So a full 30 minutes extra might be needed! 
This is a good recipe if you have a chicken you need to roast.  But, with the cost to buy a fresh rotisserie, costing and tasting the same pretty much, I would probably only make again if I just happen to have a whole chicken to bake.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gotta confess. I really *really* wanted to follow this recipe to the letter, but I ran into a problem: my grocery store was out of chickens! After a long bit of thought looking at the sorely lacking poultry shelves, I decided on a little (okay, not so little) tray of thighs. I liberally salted, peppered and onion powdered both sides of the thighs, laid them skin-side up on a broiler pan and proceeded with the directions. (I did skip the butter or butter-substitute products and the celery altogether given my predicament, and went with the original cooking time as the thighs were slightly frozen when I started.) I cooked to 180 degrees (took exactly an hour) and turned off the oven. 30 minutes later, I had the best-tasting thighs I'd ever had. I had set out on this journey to have a roasted chicken to use to make soup. I settled on thighs because I prefer dark meat. I ate only one of these jewels as is and will use the rest for the soup, but I have little doubt that I'll be revisiting this recipe again soon. Thanks for the amazing technique!

honestly...I can't put into words how good this was! i had an awful day and wanted some comfort food, but did not feel like making a huge hassle out of cooking...this recipe was PERFECT. I made it just as the recipe said, except threw some onion in the cavity along with the celery. I got baste happy with it (mostly because it smelled so good i wanted to keep looking at it!) and it had a perfect browned skin! I bet the gravy made with this is delicious, but honestly you don't need gravy because it is that moist! I will never make roast chicken differently...your grandma is an angel!

text:
Very tasty! I used 1 tbsp butter in cavity and 1 tbsp on top. I put 2 crushed garlic cloves and a sprig of rosemary in the cavity. I put 1 sprig of rosemary, stalk of celery and a quartered onion in the roasting pan with water to stop them from burning.  If your chicken has a "slimy bottom" as someone had mentioned, use a rack in your roaster, which I did or buy air chilled chickens VS water chilled since they have no added water.

text:
Best chicken recipe....ever. I can't even tell you how much I love this chicken. It is so juicy and so delicious. Follow the recipe exactly (at least the first time you make it) and do not add any additional seasonings. I do recommend cutting the butter by 1/3 or so because you really do not need that much for it to turn out as juicy as ever. Season it liberally, baste every 20 minutes or so, and reap the rewards of your minimal labor later. This recipe is soooo good. 10 stars!

text:
I'd give this recipe 4 stars without my adjustments. First of all, I stuffed the cavity with carrots and onions along with celery. Also, we used real butter and a lot more onion powder than called for. Instead of putting the butter on the outside of the chicken, we put it underneath the skin. We used a probe thermometer during cooking and the chicken took longer than stated to reach 180 degrees F. Overall, this recipe was very good and we will definitely make it again.

text:
I have made this chicken many, many times. My husband and I live alone and this makes enough for our dinner with leftovers for lunch the next day. I follow the recipe pretty much. I place the chicken in a large roasting pan so I had lots of space around the chicken for vegetables. I add sliced potatoes, baby carrots, squash, bell peppers and onion. It makes a one pan meal. About halfway thru baking I baste with some chicken broth to keep the veggies moist. The left overs can also be used for chicken salad. Mmmmm, So good!

text:
Very juicy and delicious! Easy to make and kids love it! I made 2 at the same time being we have a large family and I cooked it for 1 1/2 hours. I used 1/2 stick butter on the inside and 1/2 stick butter on the outside of each chicken. I am really glad I found this recipe. Nice change of pace for us. Try using your left over chicken in chicken salad.. VERY GOOD!! YUMMMM! Thank you for sharing!

text:
I really can't say enough about how easy, tasty and JUICY this chicken is!! Due to lacking ingredients in my pantry I did make some minor changes.  I substituted garlic powder for the onion powder and also placed some chopped onion in the cavity w/ the celery.  I also used unsalted butter rather than margarine, some of which I also placed up under the skin. To my whole families delight this was the best and juiciest chicken we have ever eaten!!  To be certain it is much better than any store bought broasted chicken!!! Only thing I would change is using all the wonderful drippings to make gravy and serve w/ mashed potatoes next time!! Thanks for such a wonderful recipe!!!

text:
This was a really simple and delicious recipe.  A great place to start with roasted chicken.  It is the technique not the seasonongs that make this an excellent recipe.  What my husband and I liked was it became 3 meals.  Day 1 we had roasted chicken dinner with all the trimmings.  Day 2 chicken fajitas.  And day 3 bean soup.I boiled the rest of the chicken: bones and all, until all loosened off the bone.  Pulled all the bones out, added the celery out of the rib cage, and the gravy. Best bean soup we have ever had!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1020142.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is outstanding! Who knew something so simple could taste so good! My husband is allergic to onion and garlic powder so I put a medium onion cut in half along with several smashed garlic gloves in the cavity. I rubbed under the skin with butter, salt and pepper as others recommended.  The day I planned to make this, my husband removed the oven to make way for a new one. So I put it in a disposable pan on the grill upside down the first 30 minutes, then turned. I filled another disposable pan with baby carrots, new potatoes and quartered onions tossed in olive oil, salt & pepper. Cover the first 30 minutes and toss when you baste the chicken. It was a great meal with no clean up!! Can't wait to try this chicken in my new oven!!

userID:
3063869
Display Name:
Sarah Ruckstuhl
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7260760.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like the other reviewers, I was a bit skeptical when I first looked at the ingredient list.  I thought, how could this be the best chicken ever? There is nothing even close to a "secret ingredient".  I following the recipe except used garlic salt instead of onion salt, and put 3 cloves of garlic in with the celery.  When I first saw it cooking, there wasn't much juice around the bird, and I was thinking it was going to be dry.  Boy was I wrong!  I'm not sure if the salt on the outside is what does it (by causing the bird to retain moisture, similar the effect of brining) or what, but when I cut into the chicken, it was like the floodgates opened...all the juice was inside where it should be!  It was the most tender, delicious chicken ever!  This will be a regular in my dinner menu!

text:
I'm happy to say that my chicken came out great! This was my very first roast chicken. I used salt, pepper, paprika and garlic powder to flavor it. I cooked it breast up for a while, and then turned it breast down for the duration of cooking. I served it with Jasmine rice, and used the gravy/drippings from the chicken to flavor the rice. It was delicious, and was just like the chickens my mom makes. I felt like such a grown up! :P

text:
I decided to use this recipe after doing some internet research and the chicken came out great! We adjusted the recipe slightly - we used some mixed up salt which included some garlic power and mixed pepper from penzey's spices. We also put a few pats of butter in the skin of the chicken (sim to how you prep a turkey for thanksgiving.) we also put a few shallots into the cavity along with some of the celery.) The turkey came out up super juicey and yummy. We will be sure to use this recipe again!

text:
I don't understand how this recipe works, but it did indeed make the juiciest chicken I've ever had.  When I cut into the breast meat, juices literally poured out like the chicken had been submerged in water.  The only thing I did differently was add a little lemon pepper to the seasoning outside.  I might experiment with other seasonings as well, like blackened/cajun spice, Greek seasoning, etc.  This will definitely be the recipe I use for every roast chicken I prepare for the rest of my life.

text:
Easy. Juicy.  I used a 6 lb. chicken - took 2 hrs.  Many roasted chicken recipes call for water or broth in the pan, the margarine bastes as the chicken bakes (not steams).  With the margarine drippings mixing with the chicken, it makes a great broth to cook veggies in. May be the best broccoli I've ever had.

I followed the recipe exactly and the
chicken was precisely as promised...
perfect.
I have tried roasting chicken following
the directions of, to name a few, James
Beard, Julia Child, Graham Kerr ... and
the beat goes on.  Forget about 'em.
This is not only the best, it's the
simplest.
I have changed the spice rub to one more
suitable to my taste.  But this recipe
never promised "like Mama used to make"
flavor, it promised juicy roasted 
chicken.  And does it ever deliver.
Many, many thanks Robinrockingbird.

text:
I'm a vegetarian but was cooking for meat-eating guests.  I made this recipe using cornish game hens.  All but one guest (and she asked for the rest of her's to be wraped to go) ate their entire hen and raved about how tender and juicy and tasty it was!  I was curious because the ingredients seem so simple, but wow!  It almost made me want to eat one when I heard what my guests had to say!  For 5 hens, I cooked them in a roasting pan for 1.5 hours and let them sit covered out of the oven for half an hour.

I am rating this 5 stars because it is so stinkin' easy and the ingredients are those that most of us have on hand (generally speaking I mean I don't normally have chickens lying around).

text:
This is delicious and I actually slow cooked mine in a crock. As tasty as it is slow cooked, I'm sure it is even better roasted and can't wait to have the time to monitor it. I liberally sprinkled onion powder and salt and pepper inside and out. I also put more celery as I just filled the inner cavity. If you slow cook, put breast side down. It won't look pretty, but it will stay moister!

UPDATE- I did this properly in the oven and my husband loved it! It was so crispy and delicious. If you could do this in a rotisserie- WOW!

text:
I am teaching my girlfriend how to cook and needed to find a foolproof recipe that would not intimidate her and that would taste great and boost her confidence. I would have not chosen this recipe if I had just looked at the ingredients, because I normally add more herbs and spices to my roast chickens, and just adding onion powder, butter, celery, salt, and pepper sounded a little dull. However, after seeing the amount of people who rated it a 5, I had to try it. I was not disappointed. It was the most delicious and most juicy roast chicken I've ever made. There is something magic in this recipe. I was tempted to add garlic powder and stuff some herbs in the cavity, but I stuck to the recipe to see if it was really THAT good. The only thing I may have done a little differently is be more liberal with my onion powder. Thank you so much for a delicious addition to my permanent recipe file!  I can't wait to make it again with my friend:-)
